835795201.title: Performance Issue: Check if github.IssueEvent.IssueEvent has an Assignee takes long
835795201.description:
Case:

I want to read out the information from the IssueEvent.
Not all IssueEvents have an Assignee/Assigner.

Minimum Code:
```{python}
import cProfile

def test(event):
    if event.assignee is not None:
        return
issues = repo.get_issues(state='all')
for issue in issues:
    for event in issue.get_events():
        cProfile.run("test(event)")
        cProfile.run("test(event)")
```

Results

1.  **event.assignee is None:**
      First Run:
      6182 function calls (6158 primitive calls) in 0.236 seconds
      Second Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds
2. **event.assignee is not None:**
      First Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds
      Second Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds

Is there a faster way to check if IssueEvent has an Assignee?

I have the same problem with Labels and Assigner too.

833834360.title: Bug in repr(PublicKey)
833834360.description:
hi there.

there is a bug in "repo.get_public_key".

i found this bug by trying to use "repo.create_secret", which failed because of this issue

```
repo.get_public_key()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/sschultchen/PycharmProjects/IAC_Main/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/PublicKey.py", line 55, in __repr__
    return self.get__repr__({"key_id": self._key_id.value, "key": self._key.value})
  File "/Users/sschultchen/PycharmProjects/IAC_Main/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 62, in value
    raise GithubException.BadAttributeException(
github.GithubException.BadAttributeException: (1, <class 'str'>, None)
```

i guess the reason for this might be that the pygithub implementation assumes that "key_id" is a string, but it actually is a integer.

at least, the github api gives me an integer, and not a string for this attribute.

831046278.title: Documentation - Features for unreleased versions
831046278.description:
I'm currently in the early stages of a project which will use this module, and based on the docs found [here](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest), the project currently supports creation of repository secrets, which is a feature that I require. However, upon further inspection, this appears to be a v2.0.0 feature which is not released on PyPi yet. 

Is it possible to either make the `latest` version on `ReadTheDocs` refer to the latest release version, or alternatively at least mark features that do not exist in the latest version as such in the documentation? This isn't an "end of the world" thing, but it confused me for a bit, and took some searching to understand why the feature I was reading about in the documentation was not available on an up-to-date installation.

Thanks for all you do! This project is super useful, and well documented. :)

828533735.title: Add support for the 'visibility' attribute on the Repository object
828533735.description:
Adds support for [the 'visibility' attribute](https://developer.github.com/changes/2019-12-03-internal-visibility-changes/) on the Repository object. Closes https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1446.

I updated the affected replay tests manually (not seeing a BeaverSoftware org?). I added the header to reflect the new request we'll send, and added `"visibility":"public"` next to `"private":false` in all response objects.

I also smoke tested this against our real enterprise account:

```
$ python3
Python 3.9.1 (default, Jan 30 2021, 15:51:05) 
[Clang 12.0.0 (clang-1200.0.32.29)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import github
>>> g = github.Github("<token>")
>>> repos = list(g.get_organization("my-enterprise").get_repos())
>>> repos[0].private
False
>>> repos[0].visibility
'public'
>>> repos[10].private
True
>>> repos[10].visibility
'internal'
>>> g.get_organization("my-enterprise").get_repo("my-repo").private
True
>>> g.get_organization("my-enterprise").get_repo("my-repo").visibility
'internal'
>>> g.get_organization("my-enterprise").create_repo(name="quick-test", visibility="internal")
Repository(full_name="my-enterprise/quick-test")
# verified this is internal
>>> g.get_organization("my-enterprise").create_repo(name="quick-test-2", private=True)
Repository(full_name="my-enterprise/quick-test-2")
# verified this is private
```

Thank you for the useful library and taking the time to consider this contribution!

827237482.title: top-level directory in tarball is different when using `get_latest_release()` than on the tags page
827237482.description:
Hello,
i'm not even sure it's a _bug_ in PyGithub or somewhere else, but here's what i have:

if i go [here](https://github.com/pydata/pydata-sphinx-theme/tags) and download v0.4.3 tar.gz (fullurl: https://github.com/pydata/pydata-sphinx-theme/archive/v0.4.3.tar.gz) i end up with a tarball that has as top-level directory `pydata-sphinx-theme-0.4.3`

but if i try to do a similar operation with PyGithub:

```
In [82] g = Github()

In [83]: repo = g.get_repo("pydata/pydata-sphinx-theme")

In [84]: repo.get_latest_release().tarball_url
Out[84]: 'https://api.github.com/repos/pydata/pydata-sphinx-theme/tarball/v0.4.3'
```

and then download that URL, the resulting tarball has a top-level directory name `pydata-pydata-sphinx-theme-0528853`; the content is exactly the same, just the top-level dir is different

now, i can clearly see the URLs are different, but why they top-level directory is too? it's not repo-dependent.

is there a better way to download the same tarball i'd get from the GH tags page via PyGithub? i hope that's not something like `"https://github.com/USER/REPO/archive/"{}'.tar.gz'` cause that'd suck :)

thanks!

815840213.title: get_stats_commit_activity gets into an infinite loop if the url returns 202 status code
815840213.description:
```python
from github import Github

g = Github("access_token")

# All these urls have the same problem
# get_stats_commit_activity() returns 202 and the operation gets into an infinite loop
url = "chromium/chromium"
# url = "WebKit/WebKit-http"
# url = "JetBrains/MPS"
# url = "mozilla/gecko-dev"
# url = "Asoul/tsec"
# url = "google/mozc"
# url = "jlippold/tweakCompatible"
# url = "Katee/git-bomb"
# url = "mandatoryprogrammer/TLDR"
# url = "stevenliuyi/covid19"
# url = "zapret-info/z-i"

repo = g.get_repo(url)
activity = repo.get_stats_commit_activity()
print(activity)
```

The problem is related to the following block in the `Requester.py` file.

```python
if status == 202 and (
	verb == "GET" or verb == "HEAD"
):  # only for requests that are considered 'safe' in RFC 2616
	time.sleep(Consts.PROCESSING_202_WAIT_TIME)
	return self.__requestRaw(original_cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, input)
```

If you want to check the issue in unit tests, there are two mock responses defined for `testStatisticsCommitActivity` method:

```
https
GET
api.github.com
None
/repos/jacquev6/PyGithub/stats/commit_activity
{'Authorization': 'Basic login_and_password_removed', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'}
None
202
[('status', '202 Accepted'), ('x-ratelimit-remaining', '4964'), ('x-github-media-type', 'github.beta; format=json'), ('x-content-type-options', 'nosniff'), ('access-control-expose-headers', 'ETag, Link, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes'), ('x-github-request-id', '4C79374B:3448:429A229:528030EA'), ('content-length', '2'), ('server', 'GitHub.com'), ('x-ratelimit-limit', '5000'), ('access-control-allow-credentials', 'true'), ('date', 'Mon, 11 Nov 2013 01:20:42 GMT'), ('access-control-allow-origin', '*'), ('content-type', 'application/json; charset=utf-8'), ('x-ratelimit-reset', '1384134844')]
{}

https
GET
api.github.com
None
/repos/jacquev6/PyGithub/stats/commit_activity
{'Authorization': 'Basic login_and_password_removed', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'}
None
200
[...]
```

If you remove the second response with 200 code and only keep the 202 response, you can see that the unit test fails.

If you could let me know how to solve the problem, I could try to send you a PR, together with its unit test.

Thank you! 🙏

Related issue: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1108

815080145.title: Update token used by requester
815080145.description:
I'm using PyGithub in a Github app and use some logic to manage tokens and to refresh when necessary.

It would be helpful if there was a mechanism in `Github` objects to update the token used by the requester and to reset its `__authorizationHeader`.

This looks like it would be straight-forward enough and I'd be happy to contribute, but I'd want to make sure I consider any other use cases and how they ought to be included.

For example, is it enough to include something along the following lines?

```py
# Requester.py
class Requester:
    def update_login_or_token(self, login_or_token):
        self.__authorizationHeader = "token " + login_or_token


# MainClass.py
class Github:
    def update_login_or_token(self, login_or_token):
        self.__requester.update_login_or_token(login_or_token)
```

812186829.title: Add default arguments to Workflow method type annotations
812186829.description: The type annotations for `Workflow.create_dispatch()` and `Workflow.get_runs()` do not include the fact that some of the arguments have default values.  As a result, user code that calls, say, `workflow.get_runs()` without specifying any arguments will not validate with mypy.  This PR fixes that.

808823954.title: Error logging in with username and password.
808823954.description:
I am writing a project that should be able to allow specific users to automatically perform some actions on some file contents after logging in. I tried to alter some of the code and I'm getting some strange behaviour.

I have scoured the internet and I am literally using the exact documented code as copy and pasted, yet it always returns: github.GithubException.GithubException: 401 {"message": "Requires authentication", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/users#get-the-authenticated-user"}. 

My username and password are correct before you ask. I have run my code with PATkey tokens to ensure the rest of it works, but I obviously cannot distribute those publicly. The passwordbox function will return the string password put into this, so this isn't the issue either. From what I gather, this code should run perfectly fine, but it doesn't for me: 
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/introduction.html
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46524697/login-problems-using-pygithub

I can't find _any_ working examples of logging in with username and password, only tokens. Is it possible my code is not the issue?

Here is my code which causes the error: 
```python
from github import Github
from easygui import passwordbox  # This works similarly to getpass, but works for pycharm without going to terminal. 

def login():
    # Ask for login details
    username = input("Username? ")
    _password = passwordbox("Please enter your password for user: {} ".format(username))

    # Login
    g = Github(username, _password)
    del _password 
    user = g.get_user()
    
    login = user.login
    print("Login Successful!")

login()
```
I hope that I'm an idiot and that the solution is simple. I understand that the initial github instance is unauthorised, but that error message tells that I am required to login before I login?! Surely

802133762.title: How can I retrieve _ALL_ issues from an Organization that I manage?
802133762.description:
In the web interface I can easily retrieve/access all issues directly from the issues subsection, simply by setting `user:ORGANIZATION`  in the filtered search. 

The url for this is also simple:
 - https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+user%3AORGANIZATION+archived%3Afalse

and if I set `ORGANIZATION` to the organization I manage the results populate.  There are multiple linked repositories so it is important to be able to get _all_ issues to manage a new release and accompanying notes.

I cannot for the life of me figure out how to achieve this either via PyGithub or directly via the API, as both appear to restrict the returned issues list to the `authenticated user` and provide no means to 'set' this to the organization in the request params the way you can from the web interface.

The web interface also appears to return a full webpage rather than a concise JSON object suitable for parsing, so using that directly also appears to be a no-go. 

Is there any way to achieve this other than scraping the html response from the web url?

798062498.title: Add GitRelease.upload_asset_from_memory stub
798062498.description:
PyGithub v1.54.1 does not have an interface/stub for the `GitRelease.upload_asset_from_memory` method. One consequence of this is that mypy will not recognize that this method exists.

This PR adds that missing stub. There is no "code change" per se.

The types I chose for the arguments and the return type match what is documented on the [method docstring](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/GitRelease.py#L275), and from a cursory read through, appear to match what the code itself requires.

The only interesting one was the `file_like` argument. Our docstring is perhaps a little restrictive in asking for an object that ["must implement `read()`"](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/v1.54.1/github/GitRelease.py#L278) because this object [is later used](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/v1.54.1/github/Requester.py#L108) by the requests library, which has a much broader requirement of a ["Dictionary, list of tuples, bytes, or file-like object to send"](https://github.com/psf/requests/blob/v2.25.1/requests/sessions.py#L481).

Without wanting to expand the scope of this PR too much, I chose to stick to file-like objects as the docstring asks for. This type could be summed up as `IO[Any]`. My reference for that comes from noting how this argument is passed by PyGithub to requests, which passes it to urllib3, which passes it to `http.client`, which finally has a [typeshed stub](https://github.com/python/typeshed/blob/master/stdlib/http/client.pyi#L166) describing the argument as [`Union[bytes, IO[Any], Iterable[bytes], str]`](https://github.com/python/typeshed/blob/master/stdlib/http/client.pyi#L26). The `IO[Any]` one seems to fit best.

I'm not really sure how to test stubs... But here's one method that might be sufficient:

1. Save this code to `foo.py`:
    ```python
    from pathlib import Path
    from github import Github
    
    gh = Github(login_or_token="api_token")
    repo = gh.get_repo("user/repo")
    release = repo.get_release("some release")
    
    asset_path = Path("./foo.txt")
    
    with asset_path.open("rb") as asset_file:
        release.upload_asset_from_memory(
            file_like=asset_file,
            file_size=asset_path.stat().st_size,
            name="foo"
        )
    ```
2. Run `mypy foo.py` and note the error `error: "GitRelease" has no attribute "upload_asset_from_memory"`
3. Apply this patch, run mypy again, and see how the error is gone.

797111794.title: Make datetime objects timezone-aware
797111794.description: Timestamps returned by the GitHub API include timezone information, yet PyGithub throws this information away.  This can lead to wrong results in client code, as naïve timestamps are generally assumed to use the system time zone, yet the majority of timestamps returned by the API are in UTC.  This PR fixes the library to retain timezone information when parsing timestamps and always produce timezone-aware `datetime` objects.

789685795.title: Inaccurate Branch Protection Options
789685795.description: Hey :wave: I noticed that while calling the following: ``` ... branch = repository.get_branch("master") review_count = branch.get_required_pull_request_reviews().required_approving_review_count ``` The `review_count` or `required_approving_review_count` attribute will always return a number >= 1, which is not accurate especially when the `Require pull request reviews before merging` option is not checked / disabled, but in that case, it should return either Null or another value that translate for the "disabled" status. Much appreciated. Thanks!

787375484.title: Why does Repository.contents_url append a {+path} to the end?
787375484.description:
```python
>>> repo.contents_url
'https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/contents/{+path}'
>>> repo.contents_url.format_map({'+path' : 'test'})
'https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/contents/test'
```

Simply a question about the PyGitHub API; Why does the Repository.contents_url attribute return a valid contents URL with `{+path}` appended to the end? I would almost understand `{path}`, but `{+path}` seems odd to me, and I can't find anything about this online.

It is not special python formatting to use a plus sign here (and only with `str.format_map` can you easily format it). Nothing online talks about a GitHub API URL containing `{+path}` in it's API responses (unless that's exactly what's going on here and my googling failed).

Sorry for the stupid question, but this is very odd to me, and with a lack of source code for `contents_url` attribute (i.e. I can't find it, or it's returned from the API), I'm unable to answer why there is a plus sign in the formatting field.

781530134.title: Make requests pool_size configurable
781530134.description:
This allows uses to specify the `pool_size`, avoiding connections of being discarded in a threaded execution.

With `github.Github()`, in a theaded execution, we face:
```
WARNING  urllib3.connectionpool:connectionpool.py:298 Connection pool is full, discarding connection: api.github.com
WARNING  urllib3.connectionpool:connectionpool.py:298 Connection pool is full, discarding connection: api.github.com
WARNING  urllib3.connectionpool:connectionpool.py:298 Connection pool is full, discarding connection: api.github.com
...
```

With `github.Github(poll_size=number_of_threads)`, we see no WARNINGs.

775829532.title: Allow adding attributes at the end of the list

775820114.title: Adding new attribute fails in case new name is the last in the list
775820114.description:
### Problem Statement

```bash
$ python scripts/add_attribute.py Permissions triage bool
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<...>\PyGithub\scripts\add_attribute.py", line 124, in <module>
    line = lines[i].rstrip()
IndexError: list index out of range
```
--> Adding a new attribute at the end of the existing list of attributes in class `Permissions` fails.
--> In this case the last attribute name was "push", so "triage" comes last.
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/34d097ce473601624722b90fc5d0396011dd3acb/github/Permissions.py#L63-L72

### Solution Approach

In case the new attribute name will result in adding it at the end of the list of attributes, then the processing within the script at https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/scripts/add_attribute.py#L89 was already processing the next source code line which already contains the `_initAttributes` function.
Subsequently at https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/scripts/add_attribute.py#L122 `inInit` is set to `False`, but only checked again after reading already the next line. This means the following code block will never again notice the place of the `_initAttributes` and fails at the end of the file due to endless loop.

Problem can be fixed by conditionally remembering we already reached the `_initAttributes` function, so replace:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/34d097ce473601624722b90fc5d0396011dd3acb/scripts/add_attribute.py#L122

with

```python
inInit = True if line == "    def _initAttributes(self):" else False
```

775206606.title: Update pyjwt requirement from <2.0 to <3.0
775206606.description:
Updates the requirements on [pyjwt](https://github.com/jpadilla/pyjwt) to permit the latest version.
Release notes

Sourced from pyjwt's releases.

v2.0.0

Highlights

Introduce better experience for JWKs

Introduce PyJWK, PyJWKSet, and PyJWKClient.

import jwt
from jwt import PyJWKClient

kid = "NEE1QURBOTM4MzI5RkFDNTYxOTU1MDg2ODgwQ0UzMTk1QjYyRkRFQw"
url = "https://dev-87evx9ru.auth0.com/.well-known/jwks.json"


jwks_client = PyJWKClient(url)
signing_key = jwks_client.get_signing_key_from_jwt(token)


data = jwt.decode(
token,
signing_key.key,
algorithms=["RS256"],
audience="https://expenses-api",
options={"verify_exp": False},
)
print(data)

Support for JWKs containing ECDSA keys

Drop support for Python 2

Require cryptography >= 3

Drop support for PyCrypto and ECDSA

We've kept this around for a long time, mostly for environments that didn't allow installing cryptography.

Drop CLI

Dropped the included cli entry point.

Improve typings

We no longer need to use mypy Python 2 compatibility mode (comments)

Add support for Ed25519 / EdDSA

Changes

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from pyjwt's changelog.

[v2.0.0][2.0.0]

Changed

Drop support for Python 2

Require cryptography >= 3

Drop support for PyCrypto and ECDSA

We've kept this around for a long time, mostly for environments that didn't allow installing cryptography.

Drop CLI

Dropped the included cli entry point.

Improve typings

We no longer need to use mypy Python 2 compatibility mode (comments)

jwt.encode(...) return type

Tokens are returned as string instead of a byte string

Dropped deprecated errors

Removed ExpiredSignature, InvalidAudience, and InvalidIssuer. Use ExpiredSignatureError, InvalidAudienceError, and InvalidIssuerError instead.

Dropped deprecated verify_expiration param in jwt.decode(...)

Use jwt.decode(encoded, key, algorithms=["HS256"], options={"verify_exp": False}) instead.

Dropped deprecated verify param in jwt.decode(...)

Use jwt.decode(encoded, key, options={"verify_signature": False}) instead.

Require explicit algorithms in jwt.decode(...) by default

Example: jwt.decode(encoded, key, algorithms=["HS256"]).

Dropped deprecated require_* options in jwt.decode(...)

For example, instead of jwt.decode(encoded, key, algorithms=["HS256"], options={"require_exp": True}), use jwt.decode(encoded, key, algorithms=["HS256"], options={"require": ["exp"]}).

Added

Introduce better experience for JWKs

Introduce PyJWK, PyJWKSet, and PyJWKClient.

... (truncated)

Commits

774339181.title: Release a version that supports Python 3.5 and requires pyjwt<2.0.0
774339181.description:
PyGithub 1.54 is the last version that supports Python 3.5, however the broken pyjwt dependency makes it unusable in Python 3.5.
We unfortunately are not able to upgrade Python in the production system, could you kindly release a 1.54 hotfix (sth like 1.54_2) that pins pyjwt to < 2.0.0 without dropping Python 3.5 support?

Thank you!

By the way, version 1.54.1 is confusing in terms of pyjwt because it's pyjwt 2.0.0 works for Python >=3.6 (you may be noticed https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1796 is using py3.5). If PyGithub decides to drop py3.5, pinning pyjwt to <2.0.0 does not bring benefit.

771420640.title: Bad Github App auth raises generic exception, not BadCredentialsException
771420640.description:
I have code that creates a Check Run with: `gh_repo.create_run_check(name, head_sha)`.

If I mistakenly authenticated the Github object with a user token, instead of an app installation token, Github appropriately responds with:

```
403 {"message": "You must authenticate via a GitHub App.",
"documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/checks#create-a-check-run"}
```

I was trying to debug this by catching `github.BadCredentialsException`, but it seems the exception raised in this case is a generic `github.GithubException`, and thus I was unable to narrowly catch only this error.

Many thanks for considering!

770890732.title: Getting new commits sha after merging of pull request
770890732.description:
My merged pull request contains 3 commits from fork repo. Merged commits(from origin master) have different commit_sha than commits from PR (from fork repo)

I've read about merge_commit_sha (new sha for the last commit from pull request) - but it is not what I want. Also events way - the same problem. Merged event contains only 1 new commit sha(latest).

In other hand: If I check all new commits and call search_issues to find PR, sorting and etc, it will take a lot of time.

I need to find new sha for each merged commits using only pr number and repo.
 Could you please clarify - is it possible to find this info via pygithub?

753772794.title: Pinning requests breaks things if urllib3 is already installed
753772794.description:
Recently it looks like you pinned requests to <2.25 (https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/commit/d159425f36dc7f68766cc980e262e9287e5f111c) which is incompatible with urllib3>=1.26 (https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/HTTPretty/issues/409). But it looks like pip is not downgrading urllib3 if it is already installed, so perhaps it makes sense to also pin urllib3? We ran into this here: https://github.com/pangeo-data/pangeo-cloud-federation/issues/893:
```
requests 2.24.0 has requirement urllib3!=1.25.0,!=1.25.1,<1.26,>=1.21.1, but you'll have urllib3 1.26.2 which is incompatible.
```
We will pin on our side but I thought it would be worthwhile to let you know. Thanks.

Also, as the twitter_username is returned in api.github.com/user/{username}, it makes sense to get this value here.

Can I contribute to this issue?

752758162.title: example for creating and updating GitHub check run
752758162.description:
I would like my CI server to create and update GitHub check run as it does the CI builds. I plan to use PyGitHub, but I couldn't find any example on this. After hours of digging, I can to some what like the snippet below but I get a "bad credentials error". Thank you for the awesome GitHub SDK but it will be a great help, if there is an example code for this particular workflow. 



```
import jwt
import time
from github import Github

pem_file = "ci-results.2020-11-27.private-key.pem"
installation_id = 111
app_id = 111

time_since_epoch_in_seconds = int(time.time())
payload = {
    # issued at time
    'iat': time_since_epoch_in_seconds,
    # JWT expiration time (10 minute maximum)
    'exp': time_since_epoch_in_seconds + (5 * 60),
    # GitHub App's identifier
    'iss': app_id
}

this_jwt = jwt.encode(payload, open(pem_file, 'r').read().strip().encode(), 'RS256').decode()

gh = Github(jwt=this_jwt)

gh.get_app("ci-results")
```


github.GithubException.BadCredentialsException: 401 {"message": "Bad credentials", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest

749096413.title: making PyGithub citable
749096413.description:

* more involved: write a [JOSS article](https://joss.readthedocs.io/en/latest/submitting.html)

748490771.title: Update requests requirement from <2.25,>=2.14.0 to >=2.14.0,<2.26
748490771.description:
Updates the requirements on [requests](https://github.com/psf/requests) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from requests's changelog.

2.25.0 (2020-11-11)

Improvements

  • Added support for NETRC environment variable. (#5643)

Dependencies

  • Requests now supports urllib3 v1.26.

Deprecations

  • Requests v2.25.x will be the last release series with support for Python 3.5.
  • The requests[security] extra is officially deprecated and will be removed in Requests v2.26.0.

2.24.0 (2020-06-17)

Improvements

  • pyOpenSSL TLS implementation is now only used if Python either doesn't have an ssl module or doesn't support SNI. Previously pyOpenSSL was unconditionally used if available. This applies even if pyOpenSSL is installed via the requests[security] extra (#5443)

  • Redirect resolution should now only occur when allow_redirects is True. (#5492)

  • No longer perform unnecessary Content-Length calculation for requests that won't use it. (#5496)

2.23.0 (2020-02-19)

Improvements

  • Remove defunct reference to prefetch in Session __attrs__ (#5110)

Bugfixes

  • Requests no longer outputs password in basic auth usage warning. (#5099)

Dependencies

  • Pinning for chardet and idna now uses major version instead of minor. This hopefully reduces the need for releases everytime a dependency is updated.

747385762.title: No examples or documentation around working with pull request reviews
747385762.description:
While there are some examples on how to work with [Pull Requests](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/tree/master/doc/examples) there is effectually nothing documented around how to obtain information about the **review status** from a PR object.

As I have a specific PR, I do want to findout the CI check report on it and the current review status: if anyone approved it or requested changes, so I would figure out how far is from being ready to merge.

So far all I got was the `pull_request.url` property but how do I endup instantiating a PullRequestReview out of it? I was not able to see any example, doc or even tests doing it. After half and hour of googling and being unable to find any example, I decided that maybe we need a simple example.

744566033.title: Does this library expose the token i
744566033.description:
According to this https://github.blog/2012-09-21-easier-builds-and-deployments-using-git-over-https-and-oauth/,
 tokens are exposed:

> Note: Tokens should be treated as passwords. Putting the token in the clone URL will result in Git writing it to the .git/config file in plain text. Unfortunately, this happens for HTTP passwords, too. We decided to use the token as the HTTP username to avoid colliding with credential helpers available for OS X, Windows, and Linux.

Does this library also expose tokens if used to authenticate?

Like:

```python
g = Github(os.environ["DEV_BOT_TOKEN"])
```

We use this lib in our GH actions setup and don't want to leak tokens.

735289708.title: Potential enhancement working with forks
735289708.description:
Hi,

I'm a big fan of this project, and it has made our lives easier and better for a while now.

One of the things I'm looking at right now is to improve some of the workflows we have when working with forks. 
There's a couple of different things we do, where we want to make changes to directories via PRs, rather than directly in the repos. 

It has not been immediately obvious to me how to ensure appropriately synced forks over time without spinning out subprocess and git CLI with local repo clone, but I've just realized after coming across this stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/a/27762278/5438386 that there is a neat API centric way of doing it.
Specifically
```
Get upstream ref /repos/upstream/repo/git/refs/heads/master, and get the hash from it
Update your fork PATCH /repos/my/repo/git/refs/heads/master with the same hash.
```
From that it's easy to create a `branch_from_upstream` type function that is so central to many of our workflows.

As I'm starting to look at building out a more fork workflow centric class I wonder whether some of this would make sense to contribute upstream to this project, or if these higher level flows make most sense to keep out of this?

734935813.title: Support for artifacts API
734935813.description:
This builds further on @JacekPliszka's work, but without the metaclasses to automatically add fields to a new class (cfr. #1556; which seems interesting, but unrelated to this actual functionality). See also #1373.

This still needs tests, but I cannot immediately find any artifacts belonging to this repository. Any idea what I can use to test downloading artifacts?

Things to review/consider:
- Following the status "302 Found" redirect, needed during the download of artifacts, is handled manually, since existing tests break when adding this to `Requester.__requestRaw` (see @JacekPliszka's f69c763, and my a7fd8f2). Is this something that should be preferably be added to `Requester.__requestRaw`? I can do an effort to fix those failing tests, then.
- I had to refactor the methods of `Requester` quite a bit, in order to be able to download a binary file without trying to decode it to a unicode string. While this seems like a lot of changes, I think they should be reasonably focused. See 99bbfbe and 78e7ae3.
- https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/actions#artifacts mentions that setting "`accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json` is recommended", yet this is not done for querying JSON in general. Should I do this for the new methods, or is this a separate PR to get this done for everything?

732544938.title: Sporadically Git tree creation failure due to `base_tree is not a valid tree oid`
732544938.description:
Hello,

We use PyGithub to create PR, and sometimes get error with "base_tree is not a valid tree oid", and once this happens, the call will be constantly failing for a period of time (minutes to hours), however, the call could get back to work sometime later.
Stack trace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "gitpr3.py", line 138, in <module>
    update_pvc_name("amp-app-processing", "us-west-1a", "new_pvc", "new_ast_versions", "new_sdkdb_versions")
  File "gitpr3.py", line 54, in update_pvc_name
    tree = repo.create_git_tree(elements, base_tree=upstream.get_git_tree(upstream_master.object.sha))
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1113, in create_git_tree
    "POST", self.url + "/git/trees", input=post_parameters
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 319, in requestJsonAndCheck
    verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 342, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "base_tree is not a valid tree oid", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.19/v3/git/trees/#create-a-tree"}
```

Our code snippet, the code always fails on the last line `repo.create_git_tree`:
```
    github = Github(base_url=GITHUB_PIE, login_or_token=GAT)

    # Get upstream/master
    upstream = github.get_repo(REPO_NAME)
    upstream_master = upstream.get_git_ref("heads/master")

    repo = github.get_repo(USER_REPO)

    # We need to deal with trees and tree elements because the
    # Github repo update_file API creates one commit per-file
    # and that clutters up our Git history. This approach lets
    # us batch all the changes into a single commit.
    # We want to get files from the upstream repo, so that's what we pass in.
    elements: List[InputGitTreeElement] = get_updated_elements(
        upstream, namespace, cluster, new_pvc, ast_versions, sdkdb_versions, tapi_analyze_sdkdb_versions)

    # Construct the tree of all our changes so far, based off upstream/master
    tree = repo.create_git_tree(elements, base_tree=upstream.get_git_tree(upstream_master.object.sha))
```

Since the same script would get different results (success/failure) at different time, it looks like something wrong/inconsistent on the server side, any pointer would be appreciated, thanks!

722949128.title: create_review_comment function can't comment on comfort-fade preview
722949128.description:
In the file PullRequest.py

```
    def create_review_comment(self, body, commit_id, path, position):
        """
        :calls: `POST /repos/:owner/:repo/pulls/:number/comments <http://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/comments>`_
        :param body: string
        :param commit_id: :class:`github.Commit.Commit`
        :param path: string
        :param position: integer
        :rtype: :class:`github.PullRequestComment.PullRequestComment`
        """
        assert isinstance(body, str), body
        assert isinstance(commit_id, github.Commit.Commit), commit_id
        assert isinstance(path, str), path
        assert isinstance(position, int), position
        post_parameters = {
            "body": body,
            "commit_id": commit_id._identity,
            "path": path,
            "position": position,
        }
        headers, data = self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
            "POST", self.url + "/comments", input=post_parameters
        )
        return github.PullRequestComment.PullRequestComment(
            self._requester, headers, data, completed=True
        )
```

the code use "position" as the parameters for github pull request review comment api.

but in the docs of github api, the "position" is for

> Required without comfort-fade preview. The position in the diff where you want to add a review comment. Note this value is not the same as the line number in the file. For help finding the position value, read the note above. 

When we want to comment at the comfort-fate line, will get 

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Validation Failed", "errors": [{"resource": "PullRequestReviewComment", "code": "invalid", "field": "position"}]
```

I think that if we want to create a review comment, we will create on comfort-fate line more.

718612891.description:
I‘m trying "[GitHub Enterprise Cloud](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/getting-started-with-github/setting-up-a-trial-of-github-enterprise-cloud)", because it will improve my github api rate limit.
And the organization only provides `OAuth Apps` not `Personal access tokens` , How can I use ‘Client ID’ and ‘Client Secret’ of OAuth Apps to request github api  with PyGithub.

I user curl like this ，It works.
```shell
curl -u my_client_id:my_client_secret 'https://api.github.com/rate_limit'
```
output
```shell
{
  "resources": {
    "core": {
      "limit": 15000,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 15000,
      "reset": 1602336141
    },
    "search": {
      "limit": 30,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 30,
      "reset": 1602332601
    },
    "graphql": {
      "limit": 5000,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 5000,
      "reset": 1602336141
    },
    "integration_manifest": {
      "limit": 5000,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 5000,
      "reset": 1602336141
    },
    "source_import": {
      "limit": 100,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 100,
      "reset": 1602332601
    },
    "code_scanning_upload": {
      "limit": 500,
      "used": 0,
      "remaining": 500,
      "reset": 1602336141
    }
  },
  "rate": {
    "limit": 15000,
    "used": 0,
    "remaining": 15000,
    "reset": 1602336141
  }
}
```
The rate limit is 15000, to show that my login is valid.

But I don't Know How to user PyGithub to get the same effect.

I tried this, but it didn't work.
```pyhton 
>>> from github import Github
>>> g = Github(client_id='my_client_id', client_secret='my_client_secret')
1: FutureWarning: client_id and client_secret are deprecated and will be removed in a future release, switch to token authentication
>>> g.get_rate_limit()
RateLimit(core=Rate(reset=2020-10-10 12:39:24, remaining=42, limit=60))
# limit is 60 not 15000
```

718201239.title: OAuth access token Failure Errors are Masked
718201239.description:
I created an PyGithub OAuth application using the client ID and client secret issued by GitHub. Unfortunately, upon calling `get_access_token` on that app (with the callback code from GitHub's callback), I do not get a usable access_token. See below:

```
github_app = github.Github().get_oauth_application(CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET)
response = github_app.get_access_token(CALLBACK_CODE)
# r.token, r.scope, and r.type are all `None`, and r._token is `NotSet`
```

My PyGithub version is 1.53. Please advise; I have so far looked at #1021 .

718190713.title: `get_login_url` to support the scope parameter
718190713.description: A scope parameter (to correspond to Github's scope parameter described [here](https://developer.github.com/apps/building-oauth-apps/authorizing-oauth-apps/#1-request-a-users-github-identity)) would be great! I believe you can simply add it here: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/ApplicationOAuth.py#L58

717970022.title: github.BranchProtection.BranchProtection missing 3 attributes
717970022.description:
GitHub api provides to do the following:
-  required_linear_history: true,
-  allow_force_pushes: true,
-  allow_deletions: true

https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#update-branch-protection

The functions related to this 3 branch protection rules are not added in the class mentioned in the title.

716691870.title: Add html_url to GitTreeElement
716691870.description: Can the `html_url` property be added to `GitTreeElement` https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/GitTreeElement.html#github.GitTreeElement.GitTreeElement?

714405816.title: Project card information in issue events
714405816.description:
Adds the Accept header 'application/vnd.github.starfox-preview' to get project information in issue events. See https://developer.github.com/changes/2018-09-05-project-card-events/

Also removed 'machine-man' and 'sailor-v' previews since they have graduated to official API in August 2020. See https://developer.github.com/changes/2020-08-20-graduate-machine-man-and-sailor-v-previews/

713352458.title: Correct type hint for InputGitTreeElement.sha
713352458.description:
InputGitTreeElement.sha was previously updated to accept None to allow
files to be deleted, but the type hint was not updated.

Fixes #1707

710622474.title: Add support for deleting reactions
710622474.description:
Implements #1421 .

Note that only the following endpoints are implemented:
* DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id
* DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:issue_number/reactions/:reaction_id
* DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id
* DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/pulls/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id

For team-related endpoints, all reaction-related endpoints are not yet built according to #1249 . They'll be implemented together if reactions for teams are prioritised. I think the issue mentioned in #1249 no longer exists. The schema looks identical to `github.Reaction.Reaction`. Please comment on this part.

709613251.title: Out of date type hint for InputGitTreeElement
709613251.description:
Hello! 

In #1327, the _sha_ parameter of InputGitTreeElement was allowed to be None (in order to allow deletions through the API), but the corresponding hint was not updated:

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/7ec4f155af8d22b3fb7fd5e5788e0f7036dbda9b/github/InputGitTreeElement.pyi#L12

Many thanks in advance!

708814578.title: search_issues does not expose draft status
708814578.description:
While it is possible to include or exclude drafts when performing a search_issues query, it seems that the returned result does not include any information regarding if the returned PR is a draft one or not.

How can we gather this information?

from github import Github

org.login

708213314.title: get_organization_membership now throws a 404 error
708213314.description:
Using the following code example,`get_organization_membership` used to work in August 2020. Looks like between Aug and Sept there was either a change to the API or the code itself so that this method no longer works


Code Example for fetching members from an org and their membership

```py
import os
from github import Github

def fetch_org(access_token, org_name):
    """ create an instance of the github api """
    gh_instance = Github(login_or_token=access_token, verify=False)
    org_instance = gh_instance.get_organization(login=org_name)

    return org_instance

def fetch_members(org_instance):
    """ Fetches all members for a given org """

    return [member for member in org_instance.get_members()]

access_token = os.getenv("ACCESS_TOKEN")
org_instance = fetch_org(access_token=access_token, org_name="org-name")

members = fetch_members(org_instance)

for member in members:
    # Now throws an exception
    member.get_organization_membership('org-name')
```


Throws the following exception

```sh
github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/orgs#get-organization-membership-for-a-user"}
```

706839571.title: Adding the team-sync endpoints
706839571.description:
Using the Enterprise Team Organization it is possible to use the team synchronization feature.

https://developer.github.com/v3/teams/team_sync/#list-idp-groups-for-a-team

Making it possible to list the groups for an organization or a team.

Also adding, removing a synched group from a Team.

706704599.title: GET /repositories endpoint on Github iterate over paginated list is slow
706704599.description:
Hi!

I am trying to receive all repository names for an enterprise github server. 
Something like this:
`[repo.name for repo in gh.get_repos()]
`
Unfortunately, this is incredibly slow. The server has some 1000s of repos and it takes a couple of minutes.

I already set per_page in Github to =100.

Do you have any other suggestions how to speed this up? Is pygithub doing a single get request for every repo?
I also tested all_repositories from github3 library and this is much much faster (so the bottle neck is not my connection...) but I don't want to use an additional library...

705864894.title: 403 error for otherwise functional token
705864894.description:
The following fails on my machine:

```python
import json
from github import Github

with open("./token.json", "r") as f:
    auth_token = json.load(f)["token"]

g = Github(auth_token)

repo = next(iter(g.get_user().get_repos()))
# this fails with a 403
print(repo.get_views_traffic())
```

```
{'message': 'Must have push access to repository', 'documentation_url': 'https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#get-repository-clones'}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./requests_fails.py", line 13, in <module>
    r.raise_for_status()
  File "/home/sean/.local/share/virtualenvs/pygithub_requests_error-nXm25YLC-/home/sean/.local/share/pyenv/shims/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 941, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 403 Client Error: Forbidden for url: https://api.github.com/repos/seanbreckenridge/albums/traffic/clones
```

The token has the `repo` scope, and if I request the same using `curl`, it works fine.

![](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/7eff8b96b08c3576dd21f49fbb215c57f719f80b/68747470733a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f4f4d46724e6e4b2e706e67)

This was working fine at one point, and then just stopped. I originally found this while using <https://github.com/karlicoss/ghexport/issues/4>, you can see the process of debugging it in that issue.

I've debugged this quite a bit in the above issue, created <https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error> which has code that runs in a virtualenv which causes the error *on my machine*. Strangely, @karlicoss, who I debugged this with doesn't have the same error.

See the [log file with errrors](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/log.txt), for [this script](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/run), which runs:

- a basic `curl` with the token, which succeeds ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/curl_test.sh))
-  `PyGithub` which fails ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/pygithub_requests_fails.py))
- `requests` which fails ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/requests_fails.py))
- subclassed `PyGithub` with `httpx` [which succeeds](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/a9df0bcbf91b321e068ca591e5e6b91b804fca16/log.txt#L283-L296). ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/httpx_subclass_succeeds.py))

This seems to be a `requests` error, since even just requesting something basic to github with the python `requests` module (without `PyGithub` at all) fails (see [`./requests_fails.py`](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/requests_fails.py)), when the analogous `curl` command works fine.

So I'm not sure if this should be classified as a `PyGithub` error, or a `requests` error.

See <https://github.com/karlicoss/ghexport/issues/4#issuecomment-693694338>; in which I use `pdb` to step into right before the request is made (in `PyGithub.Requester`). If I make the request with the `requests` module, it fails. If I make it with `httpx`, it succeeds.

Similarly, I can subclass the `PyGithub.Requester` `HTTPSRequestsConnectionClass` to use [`httpx`](https://github.com/encode/httpx), and then `PyGithub` works fine. (See [`httpx_subclass_succeeds.py`](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/httpx_subclass_succeeds.py) and the output [here](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/a9df0bcbf91b321e068ca591e5e6b91b804fca16/log.txt#L283-L296)).

I suspect this is an issue with `requests`, though I'm not sure how no one else has had this issue. Apologies if this should have been posted to the `requests` module instead, but I'm not sure how to debug this any further.

705488567.title: this is to commit form version_1 to master

705080219.title: Create Team with a Team Parent and delete Team from Organization object
705080219.description:
- Making it possible to create a Team and bind it to a Parent Team.
- Also adding the possiblity to delete a Team from the Organization object instead of using only the Team Object to delete a Team.

Since the first initiative is an available option in the GitHub API, I added the parameter to the create_team() function of the Organization object, the parent team being an _int_ changed in _str_ at the url  build time. 

For the second, added the remove function like the get_team*() of the Organization object, where we can remove by name or team_id

704610134.title: Added get_installations() to Organizations
704610134.description:
closes https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1694

Added get_installations() to Organization along with tests and replay data.

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/orgs#list-app-installations-for-an-organization

```

700234586.description: This addresses issue #1615; as @s-t-e-v-e-n-k has said, I have made a new method in the Github class called get_user_by_id() which takes in the integer user id as a parameter.

700177051.title: Add the rebaseable attribute to PullRequest

700058151.title: Python PyGithub how to list projectCard?
700058151.description:

from github import Github

for project in projects:

```
thanks a lot for your help

695945421.title: Expanding the PyGithub authorization to support multiple tokens
695945421.description:
Heya!

I'm a PhD student that regularly uses PyGithub to gather data for research projects (for instance we used PyGithub to analyze the code review usage and CI usage of ~700 open-source projects, [see this paper for instance](https://cassee.dev/files/CI-silent.pdf)). When using PyGithub to make millions of GET requests over the period  of a few months we often pool the tokens of several researchers involved in the project, and use a scraper that dynamically switches tokens based on actual rate limits. 

However, writing this code is often a pain, as it requires messing with the internals of PyGithub. Recently, I started working on an update to PyGithub that allows you to pass in a list of tokens instead of a single token. Internally, PyGithub then does the switching of tokens, abstracting it away. 

However, I'm not sure if this feature is of interest to more users of PyGithub. If so, I'm open to discussing on how I could get these changes integrated into the mainline. 

P.S. Currently we're also running a study to help improve the sustainability of open-source communities, if you're open to performing in a single 60 minute interview on how you experience emotions when developing open-source software please let me know!

692790589.title: Added support for `Repository.get_workflow_runs` parameters
692790589.description:
The `/repos/:owner/:repo/actions/runs`  endpoint has 4 optional parameters which can be used to narrow down the search results. 

> Name | Type | Description
> -- | -- | --
> actor | string | Returns someone's workflow runs. Use the login for the user who created the push associated with the check suite or workflow run.
> branch | string | Returns workflow runs associated with a branch. Use the name of the branch of the push.
> event | string | Returns workflow run triggered by the event you specify. For example, push, pull_request or issue. For more information, see "Events that trigger workflows" in the GitHub Help documentation.
> status | string | Returns workflow runs associated with the check run status or conclusion you specify. For example, a conclusion can be success or a status can be completed. For more information, see the status and conclusion options available in "Create a check run."

This PR adds support for those parameters

690715078.title: Format with new black
690715078.description:
Black is very opinionated, but sometimes those opinions change. Run the
new black version across the codebase, and lock down the version used by
pre-commit so we don't get surprised like this again.

686841407.title: Issue 1655: Add authorize credentials list and removal on organization under SAML
686841407.description:
The objective is to implement the two available methods to list and remove credential ids linked to an Organization that have been Authorize by the user to act as authentication on the Organization.

Added the two endpoints available under the Organization on the GitHub API
https://developer.github.com/v3/orgs/#list-saml-sso-authorizations-for-an-organization
https://developer.github.com/v3/orgs/#remove-a-saml-sso-authorization-for-an-organization

Also needed to create a new Object to handle the return payload of the API since the raw data differs from the Authorization Object..

Added one unit test to list the credentials under an Organization, but I do not have a Organization that is  SAML protected that I can use to display in the unittest.. So I added on a personnal organization with no SAML, so an empty List is validated.

 #1655

686575157.title: Add missing preview features of Deployment and Deployment Statuses API
686575157.description:
- Enable support for deployment status states `in_progress` and `queued`
  - Add arguments `production_environment` and `transient_environment` to `Repository.create_deployment()`
  - Add attributes `production_environment` and `transient_environment` to `Deployment`
  - Fix incorrect assertion for `description` in `Deployment.create_status()`
  - Add arguments `environment`, `environment_url`, `auto_inactive` to` Deployment.create_status()`
  - Add attribute `environment_url` to `DeploymentStatus`


References:
  - https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos#deployments
  - https://developer.github.com/changes/2016-04-06-deployment-and-deployment-status-enhancements/
  - https://developer.github.com/changes/2018-10-16-deployments-environments-states-and-auto-inactive-updates/

686176980.title: Include failed requests in debug log
686176980.description:
It would be nice if Requester's debug logger logged requests that failed "below" HTTP level, eg. TCP connection failed.

If the request fails there is currently nothing logged (except a stack trace which does not tell what the attempted request was): https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L508-L536

Something like this should do the job:


```python
        status = -1
        responseHeaders = None
        output = None

        try:
            response = cnx.getresponse()

            status = response.status
            responseHeaders = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in response.getheaders())
            output = response.read()

            cnx.close()
            if input:
                if isinstance(input, IOBase):
                    input.close()
        finally:
            self.__log(verb, url, requestHeaders, input, status, responseHeaders, output)
```

684224920.title: AuthenticatedUser.get_notifications() boolean query parameters always return true.
684224920.description:
### Description

Setting `all` and `participating` filters don't filters doesn't do anything.

`all=True` and `participating=True` should filter notifications, but instead `get_notifications` always returns the full list of notifications.

### Steps to reproduce

```
from github import Github
g = Github("secret")
user = g.get_user()

# all=False is broken
notifications = user.get_notifications(all=False)

# returns 371
print(notifications.totalCount)

notifications = user.get_notifications(all=True)

# returns 371
print(notifications.totalCount)
```

>>> branch.get_required_status_checks()
Traceback (most recent call last):

675887388.title: get_git_refs() vs get_git_ref('xxxxx')
675887388.description:
While I am implementing #1628 there is a strange issue.
To get master branch GitRef, I used two different way:
```python
# function 1
master_ref1 = repo.get_git_ref('/heads/master')
```
and 
```python
# function 2
master_refs = self.github_repo.get_git_refs().get_page(0)
master_ref = None
for ref in master_refs:
    if ref.ref == "refs/heads/{}".format("master"):
        master_ref = ref
```

Then I try to commit some files with the example of below script ( same as #1628 )
```python
import github
g = github.Github(base_url="https://git.mycompany.com/api/v3",login_or_token="mytoken")
repo = g.get_repo('myorg/myrepo')
blob = repo.create_git_blob("file-content", "utf-8")
element = github.InputGitTreeElement(path="path-in-repo.ext", mode='100644', type='blob', sha=blob.sha)
head_sha = repo.get_branch('master').commit.sha
base_tree = repo.get_git_tree(sha=head_sha)
tree = repo.create_git_tree([element], base_tree)
parent = repo.get_git_commit(sha=head_sha)
commit = repo.create_git_commit("commit_message", tree, [parent])
# function 1 or function 2
master_ref.edit(sha=commit.sha)
```
And it performs differently:
```
function 1 return:
>>> master_ref.edit(sha=commit.sha)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/GitRef.py", line 91, in edit
    "PATCH", self.url, input=post_parameters
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 319, in requestJsonAndCheck
    verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 342, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 500 null
```
While `function 2` works correctly.

Could some one explain or know what is the root cause of this?
Thanks.

673248167.title: PaginatedList's totalCount is 0 if no last page
673248167.description:
When calculating totalCount for PaginatedList, if the links data does
not contain a last page, we can't know how many elements are contained
in the list. Set it to 0 in that case.

Fixes #1614

672546205.title: Correct **kwargs typing for search_*

It turns out typing for **kwargs is always Dict[str, Type], so only the
type is required.

Fixes #1633

672542856.title: Correct Repository.create_pull typing harder
672542856.description:
It turns out if an argument is optional for an overloaded method, the
type hints require the default argument specified to successfully match
against the correct signature. Furthermore, the second kind of
create_pull() does not support the draft argument at all, so remove it.

Fixes #1634

671083065.title: GithubException type-checking problem
671083065.description:
I am having a hard time to get a good solution for type-checking when I have GithubException given this interface:

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/6eba4506d4d44892c5e224054b809003fc3326f6/github/GithubException.pyi

Let me use give a practical use example to reproduce:

```
import github # PyGithub
g = github.Github("access_token")
github_repo = "staticdev/git-portfolio"
repo = g.get_repo(github_repo)
try:
    created_pr = repo.create_pull(
        title="title", body="body", head="head", base="base", draft=False,
    )
except github.GithubException as github_exception:
    extra = ""
    for error in github_exception.data["errors"]:
        if "message" in error:
            extra += f"{error['message']} "
        else:
            extra += f"Invalid field {error['field']}. "
```

When I check this code with mypy for example I get the errors:

```
src/git_portfolio/mypy.py:13:31: error: Invalid index type "str" for "Union[str, Dict[str, str]]"; expected type "Union[int, slice]"  [index]
                extra += f"{error['message']} "
                                  ^
src/git_portfolio/mypy.py:15:45: error: Invalid index type "str" for "Union[str, Dict[str, str]]"; expected type "Union[int, slice]"  [index]
                extra += f"Invalid field {error['field']}. "
```

Proposed solution: after opening an [issue on Mypy](https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/9221), @Akuli suggested using [TypedDict](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0589/) which I found great.

comments.667798582: This seems to include ``error`` is still a list inside the loop based on my reading? Are you able to perform a little more debugging on what variables are what types?

665763913.title: create_repo() does not handle repo names with " " (White-spaces)

```

```
when creating repositories using `create_repo` with names than have " " (Spaces) in them.

* Replacing the spaces with a hyphen "-" 
* By throwing a better exception which explains the problem.

I would personally lean towards the "-" replacement as users would anyways replace the spaces with hyphens.

662174607.title: get_user does not support retrieving user information by ID
662174607.description:
I'm writing a script that interfaces with both ZenHub and GitHub (using PyGithub). ZenHub only identifies users by their user id (databaseId), so if I want to find the name of the user associated with an id, I have to query GitHub's API. There's an 
[undocumented endpoint](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11976393/get-github-username-by-id) for this (`/user/:id`). 

A quick example. (My user id is 23219746.) I'm on `PyGithub==1.43.5` but I can see this is still the case on v1.51.

```pycon
>>> import github
>>> g = github.Github("...")
>>> g.get_user(g.get_user().id)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/natan/DataBiosphere/azul/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/MainClass.py", line 226, in get_user
    assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str), login
AssertionError: 23219746
```

Does PyGithub support undocumented endpoints? If so, it seems trivial to add support for this:

```diff
diff --git a/github/MainClass.py b/github/MainClass.py
index cadd1ff5..b450492a 100644
--- a/github/MainClass.py
+++ b/github/MainClass.py
@@ -261,18 +261,25 @@ class Github(object):
         :param login: string
         :rtype: :class:`github.NamedUser.NamedUser` or :class:`github.AuthenticatedUser.AuthenticatedUser`
         """
-        assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str), login
+        assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str) or isinstance(login, int), login
         if login is github.GithubObject.NotSet:
             return AuthenticatedUser.AuthenticatedUser(
                 self.__requester, {}, {"url": "/user"}, completed=False
             )
-        else:
+        elif isinstance(login, str):
             headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
                 "GET", "/users/" + login
             )
             return github.NamedUser.NamedUser(
                 self.__requester, headers, data, completed=True
             )
+        else:
+            headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
+                "GET", "/user/" + login
+            )
+            return github.NamedUser.NamedUser(
+                self.__requester, headers, data, completed=True
+            )
 
     def get_users(self, since=github.GithubObject.NotSet):
         """
```

comments.664059371: If we were to do this, it would be via another method, MainClass.get_user_by_id() or such -- are you certain the endpoint is undocumented?

658225530.title: Update sphinx requirement from <3 to <4
658225530.description:
Updates the requirements on [sphinx](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from sphinx's changelog.

Release 3.1.2 (released Jul 05, 2020)

Incompatible changes

  • #7650: autodoc: the signature of base function will be shown for decorated functions, not a signature of decorator

Bugs fixed

  • #7844: autodoc: Failed to detect module when relative module name given
  • #7856: autodoc: AttributeError is raised when non-class object is given to the autoclass directive
  • #7850: autodoc: KeyError is raised for invalid mark up when autodoc_typehints is 'description'
  • #7812: autodoc: crashed if the target name matches to both an attribute and module that are same name
  • #7650: autodoc: function signature becomes (*args, **kwargs) if the function is decorated by generic decorator
  • #7812: autosummary: generates broken stub files if the target code contains an attribute and module that are same name
  • #7806: viewcode: Failed to resolve viewcode references on 3rd party builders
  • #7838: html theme: List items have extra vertical space
  • #7878: html theme: Undesired interaction between "overflow" and "float"

Release 3.1.1 (released Jun 14, 2020)

Incompatible changes

  • #7808: napoleon: a type for attribute are represented as typed field

Features added

  • #7807: autodoc: Show detailed warning when type_comment is mismatched with its signature

Bugs fixed

  • #7808: autodoc: Warnings raised on variable and attribute type annotations
  • #7802: autodoc: EOFError is raised on parallel build
  • #7821: autodoc: TypeError is raised for overloaded C-ext function
  • #7805: autodoc: an object which descriptors returns is unexpectedly documented
  • #7807: autodoc: wrong signature is shown for the function using contextmanager
  • #7812: autosummary: generates broken stub files if the target code contains
Commits
  • 1cb5fa2 Bump to 3.1.2 final
  • d83d592 Merge pull request #7878 from mgeier/float-clearing
  • c40cb79 Update CHANGES for PR #7878
  • 3098aba basic CSS: apply "clearfix" to admonitions etc.
  • 045fc68 basic CSS: remove overflow-x from admonition/topic, allow more "floating"
  • 3e64373 Merge pull request #7916 from tk0miya/7650_signatures_for_decorator
  • 9b74e6c autodoc: the signature of base function will be shown for decorated functions
  • cc4534d Update CHANGES for PR #7852
  • 2cc6264 Merge pull request #7852 from mgeier/basic-css-simple-lists

658211436.title: Create Dependabot config file
658211436.description:
:wave: Dependabot is moving natively into GitHub! This pull request migrates your configuration from Dependabot.com to a config file, using the [new syntax](https://help.github.com/en/github/administering-a-repository/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates). When you merge this pull request, we'll swap out `dependabot-preview` (me) for a new `dependabot` app, and you'll be all set!

With this change, you'll now use the [Dependabot page in GitHub](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/network/updates), rather than the [Dependabot dashboard](https://app.dependabot.com/), to monitor your version updates. Dependabot is now configured exclusively using config files.



The new version does not yet support private git dependencies. If you use these we recommend recommend leaving Dependabot Preview active.








If you've got any questions or feedback for us, please let us know by creating an issue in the [dependabot/dependabot-core](https://github.com/dependabot/dependabot-core/issues) repository.

[Learn more about the relaunch of Dependabot](https://github.blog/2020-06-01-keep-all-your-packages-up-to-date-with-dependabot/)

Please note that regular `@dependabot` commands do not work on this pull request.

:robot::yellow_heart:

658178874.title: Check for updates to GitHub Actions every weekday
658178874.description: Now that dependabot is native to GitHub and the fact that this project makes use of GitHub actions, I think it would be nice if dependabot were to send automatic PR's of version bumps to outdated GitHub actions.

657602300.title: Add support for requested_reviewers on PullRequest
657602300.description:
This is helpful for detecting when someone has asked for a rereview on a
pull request review.

657405572.title: Help accessing issue event body
657405572.description:
Hi there, I am a bit stuck and would love some help if possible.

I am trying to access the date that an issue was opened/closed. I believe I should do this through the issue events, but so far I have only been able to see a list of issue events with ids (like `IssueEvent(id=2633664990)`). I saw that in some cases calling `.body` works to access the content itself, but that doesn't seem to be the solution here. 

Any ideas? Here is basically what I am doing:

```
repo = Github.get_repo("some_repo")
issues = repo.get_issues()

for issue in issues:
    for event in issue.get_events():
        print(event)
```

Thank you :)

656842953.title: Is it possible to get the hyperlinks of issues' body?
656842953.description:
For example, this issue has some hyperlinks on it:

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/874

I'd like to get those links, is there a way to do it?

comments.658431212: Github API doesn't seem to provide this functionality directly - but I think you could try parsing the body of an issue as Markdown.

656298436.title: Work around GitHub Organization URL bug
656298436.description:
GitHub is returning incorrect URL values for organizations. Work around
this by correcting them.

Fixes: #1598

comments.657948079:

```bash
$ curl -s -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json" https://api.github.com/repos/enarx/enarx | jq '.organization'
{
  "login": "enarx",
  "id": 44877733,
  "node_id": "MDEyOk9yZ2FuaXphdGlvbjQ0ODc3NzMz",
  "avatar_url": "https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/44877733?v=4",
