507106176.title: Raise branch not found exception as unknown object
507106176.description:
fixes #1242 

Before:
```python
Python 3.6.5 (default, Apr 25 2018, 14:26:36) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.0.0 (clang-900.0.39.2)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from github import Github
>>> gh = Github()
>>> repo = gh.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> repo.get_branch(branch="notfound")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1383, in get_branch
    self.url + "/branches/" + branch
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 268, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 279, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 404 {"message": "Branch not found", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#get-branch"}
```

After:
```python
>>> repo.get_branch(branch="notfound")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1383, in get_branch
    self.url + "/branches/" + branch
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 268, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 279, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Branch not found", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#get-branch"}
```

The new behaviour is more consistent with other 404 API exceptions, like `get_issue`.
```python
>>> repo.get_issue(number=8888)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1996, in get_issue
    self.url + "/issues/" + str(number)
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 268, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "/Users/qh812/work/role_expt/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 279, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/#get-a-single-issue"}
```

505528575.title: Handle unicode strings when recording responses (#1253)
505528575.description: The string handled had some muddled assumptions about binary vs. string vs. unicode data. I updated to assume unicode at all times and added test coverage. I also tried running a test with the `--record` function to validate in practice.

504909593.title: `RecordingConnection` string handling issues
504909593.description:
I was working on test coverage for topic search (see #1252). When recording an example API response, the test runner got thrown off by a non-breaking space in the content:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tests/Topic.py", line 67, in testSearch
    self.assertListKeyEqual(self.g.search_topics("python"), attrgetter("name"), expected_names)
  File "tests/Framework.py", line 312, in assertListKeyEqual
    realKeys = [key(element) for element in elements]
  File "github/PaginatedList.py", line 61, in __iter__
    newElements = self._grow()
  File "github/PaginatedList.py", line 73, in _grow
    newElements = self._fetchNextPage()
  File "github/PaginatedList.py", line 198, in _fetchNextPage
    headers=self.__headers
  File "github/Requester.py", line 268, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "github/Requester.py", line 328, in requestJson
    return self.__requestEncode(cnx, verb, url, parameters, headers, input, encode)
  File "github/Requester.py", line 381, in __requestEncode
    status, responseHeaders, output = self.__requestRaw(cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, encoded_input)
  File "github/Requester.py", line 405, in __requestRaw
    response = cnx.getresponse()
  File "tests/Framework.py", line 129, in getresponse
    self.__writeLine(output)
  File "tests/Framework.py", line 140, in __writeLine
    self.__file.write(line + '\n')
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xa0' in position 2437: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I haven't looked too closely at the code, but this looks related to the fact that this class treats the response body as ASCII and UTF-8 in different places.

There's another issue with the same line in Python 3. Files opened in binary mode expect to receive bytes and `'\n'` is a string.

504897998.title: Expand Topic class and add test coverage
504897998.description: I changed the parent class of `Topic` since it doesn't come with a URL that can be used to pull any missing fields.

504839104.title: Specify scope of flake8 to reduce runtime
504839104.description: On my computer, it worked out to ~15 vs. ~30 seconds.

504818414.title: Stop ignoring unused imports and remove them
504818414.description: I noticed some unused imports, so I removed the ignore directive and did the necessary cleanup. The most changes were made to the `AllTests` module. I verified there weren't any regressions by running this suite before and after, ensuring that the same number of tests ran each time (573).

504791683.title: Add support for team discussions (#1246)
504791683.description:
This patch adds support for a feature in preview. This seemed reasonable since a number of other similar features have been added. I tested by writing a unit test with mock data that replicates the format of a real response. I also tested on a GitHub Enterprise instance and was able to access expected data.

I omitted implementing the ability to get a single comment, as well as create, edit, and delete. I'm happy to go back and do this, but I wanted to get feedback on what I've done so far since this is my first PR.

I omitted another feature, a preview feature inside the preview feature: reactions to discussions. The schema is totally different to the existing `github.Reaction.Reaction` class (and, IMO, kind of peculiar in comparison). I'd prefer deferring on this particular feature.

504733133.title: 403 {'message': 'Maximum number of login attempts exceeded. Please try again later.
504733133.description:
Hello,

I am trying to incorporate this API in my code. I am trying to simply authenticate a Github object using the code from the tutorial. I have a class that looks like this:

from github import Github

token = "some token"

# Github Enterprise with custom hostname
g = Github("url", token)

# Then play with your Github objects:
for repo in g.get_user().get_repos():
    print(repo.name)


When I run this script I get the following:
github.GithubException.GithubException: 403 {'message': 'Maximum number of login attempts exceeded. Please try again later.', 'documentation_url': 'https://developer.github.com/v3'}


Is there any way to fix this? I got this exception today and I have not tried to run this since yesterday evening. I have tried making new tokens and still get the same problem. Any help would be useful. Thank you

504690889.title: get_user() do not return an AuthenticatedUser
504690889.description:
I am trying create a repo with PyGithub, and on the [docs](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/AuthenticatedUser.html) of AuthenticatedUser is described _An AuthenticatedUser object can be created by calling get_user() on a Github object._ . But get_user is returning a NamedUser, not an AuthenticatedUser.

code example:
```python
self._login = login
self._password = password
g = Github(login, password)
g.get_user(self._login).create_repo("test")
```

503768523.title: get_labels() on a Pull Request
503768523.description:
Similar to GH-1220. 

Can you please advise on how to retrieve the *labels* on 1 pull request?
  
Your revised documentation, April 2018,  makes change to conform to GitHub API v3 in this PR: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/754/commits/8ff93f5f576dc8d4c5d6afce85c9273e5b97c73f

What's not clear to me is how I could replace `issues` with `pulls` in the above PR.

I would like an example of how to query the labels in 1 pull request (my example returns a select few).  To do so, the example could be similar to getting specific labels in open issues, like so:


```
gH      = Github("user", "password")
user    = gH.get_user('<gh-user>')
repo    = user.get_repo("<repo-name>")
pulls   = repo.get_pulls(state='all', sort='created', base='master', direction="desc")[:5]
issues   =  repo.get_issues(state="open")  

for issue in issues:
    labels = issue.labels
    label = [l.name for l in labels if l.name=='P1' or l.name=='P2' or l.name=='P3']
    print(label)
```
Alternate: In example below, I'd like to replace `issues` with `pulls`, but it doesn't work.

``` 
           for issue in issues:
                labels = issue.get_labels()
                label = [l.name for l in labels if l.name=='P1' or l.name=='P2' or l.name=='P3']
                print(label)
```

Also, in PyGitHub's docs, `labels` is an attribute of the github.PullRequest.PullRequest class. 
It's not clear whether one can pull labels on a single PR, per docs here:
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#pullrequest

503764732.title: get_labels() on a Pull Request
503764732.description:
Similar to GH-1220. 

Can you please advise on how to retrieve the *labels* on 1 pull request.
  
I see you revised documentation this past July 2019 to conform to GitHub API v3 in this PR: 
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/754/commits/8ff93f5f576dc8d4c5d6afce85c9273e5b97c73f

503264114.title: Inconsistent exception when calling get_branch with non-existent branch
503264114.description:
When [get_branch](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/020fbebcaf7067812d35bb16ce55c931f0254725/github/Repository.py#L1374) is called with a non-existent branch, a general `GithubException` is raised. This behaviour is inconsistent with other APIs like `get_repo` which raises the more specific `UnknownObjectException`.

The root cause is https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/a0f01cf9cf5521fd034813242727de72eb52df42/github/Requester.py#L307 where the checker is looking for an exact string match but the HTTP response for `get_branch` is instead:
```
{'message': 'Branch not found', 'documentation_url': 'https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#get-branch'}
```

This inconsistent behaviour makes user's error handling code unnecessarily complicated.

I wonder if there's a good way to fix this?

501750543.title: throttling/backoff for rate limits support for PyGitHub
501750543.description: There is no elegant way to implement throttling for github API calls through PyGitHub. The best way I can find to make sure my app doesn't hit the throttling limits is to keep checking before every call, and maintain a count of the number of calls made to the APIs, and then continuously checking if that limit is reached or not - while refreshing the rate limits periodically. It is not simple to implement a wrapper class, or apply decorators/descriptors to the calls because there various classes (like GitHub, Repository, Releases etc) that can make a call to the API endpoint. It seems implementing this feature inside PyGitHub to help throttle/ratelimit/wait calls would be the best approach IMO, since every call the the REST API can be tracked. Will such a feature be encouraged? Does it make sense to work on a pull request?

501036113.title: Do not allow to perform requests
501036113.description:
Hi everyone.
I am using the library for my pet project. I really like its architecture,
However, I ran into an issue or a feature of the library.
I need to retrieve information about all the issues (including pull requests) in a repository. I was surprised by the low performance of the following script.

```python
import pandas as pd
from github import Github

def load(reponame, login, password):
    # Log in to GitHub (see below)
    gh = Github(login, password, per_page=100)
    # Define the repository: reponame="user/repo"
    repo = gh.get_repo(reponame)

    # Create a pandas dataframe
    column_names = ["Created", "IsPR"]
    df_issues = pd.DataFrame(columns = column_names)

    issues = repo.get_issues(state="all")

    for issue in issues:
        df_issues.loc[issue.number] = [issue.created_at,
                    issue.pull_request != None, issue.labels, issue.milestone]
    
    return df_issues
```

The script should load up to 100 issues in one request and process them in a loop.
I have noticed that while in `for issue in issues:`, the script still utilizes network.

Digging into this weird behavior, it turned out, that PyGithub can send a request to GitHub if a property value is not set:

```python
@property
def pull_request(self):
    """
    :type: :class:`github.IssuePullRequest.IssuePullRequest`
    """
    
    self._completeIfNotSet(self._pull_request)
    if self._pull_request is NotSet:
        return None
    return self._pull_request.value
```

So when the script fetches 100 issues, `N` of them are pull requests. For those `100-N` issues the `pull_request` property value is not set. On each such issue a network request to GitHub is performed.

For my use case these http requests are useless, significantly decrease performance and sometimes make gthub to reject the request due to rate limiting.
I already have this data. required. If `self._pull_request is NotSet`, then I can safely say it is not a PR, but an issue.

I have not found a way to turn off this behavior in PyGithub's API.

I think there should be a way to tell, that I dont want further hidden request when acessing an item (`GithubObject`)
I think there should be an option to tell if hidden requests on an object are allowed.
At the moment the `_fetchNextPage` function of `PaginatedList` sets all items as not completed:
```
self.__contentClass(self.__requester, headers, element, completed=False)
```

A workaround might be to use `get_pulls` to retrieve all pull requests, but then the data is retrieved again, although it is already present when retreiving issues.

500313875.title: since arguement of get_repos
500313875.description:
Hi all! 

I am trying to use pygithub to get a list of publicly available repos on github. Rather than getting all repos available on github, I'm trying to limit it to a subset of these repos. My code is as follows:

```
from github import Github
import sys
import datetime as dt

g = Github(sys.argv[1]) // token passed as command line argument
since = dt.datetime.now() - dt.timedelta(minutes=1) // get all repos in the past minute

for repo in g.get_repos(visibility='public', since=since):
    print(repo.name)
```

This consistently throws the following error:
```
    assert since is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(since, int), since
AssertionError: 2019-09-30 10:22:20.979714
```

In the documentation it's clear the since argument is expecting an integer (see here: https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github.html ) but I cannot see how an integer could be used in this context. Can someone please explain the usage of this argument?

494887998.title: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'startswith' when trying to access UserKey attributes
494887998.description:
**Description:**

I'm trying to iterate through Github users and get their public keys.  Unfortunately I'm getting an `AttributeError` when trying to access some of the returned `UserKey` object's attributes. 

This happens whether the attributes are accessed directly or via `.raw_data`.

It looks like it's an issue with some of the attributes only being available on `AuthenticatedUser`'s keys vs a `NamedUser`'s keys.


**Steps to reproduce:**
```python
from github import Github

g = Github('access_token')

for user in g.get_users():
    keys = '\n'.join(
        f'key: {key.url}'
        for key in user.get_keys()
    )
    print(f'{user.id} {user.login}\n{keys}')
```

```python
  File "./all_github_users.py", line 27, in <genexpr>
    for key in user.get_keys()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/UserKey.py", line 82, in verified
    self._completeIfNotSet(self._verified)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 265, in _completeIfNotSet
    self._completeIfNeeded()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 269, in _completeIfNeeded
    self.__complete()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 274, in __complete
    self._url.value
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 276, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 292, in __customConnection
    if not url.startswith("/"):
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'startswith'
```

**Line causing the error:**

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/a0f01cf9cf5521fd034813242727de72eb52df42/github/Requester.py#L284


**Expected behavior:**

The attributes not available on a `NamedUser`'s keys should be `None` or not present on `UserKey`.

488208375.title: fix topics attribute always return None
488208375.description:
It resolves #1208. Fixing it is not as easy as it looks like. Currently PyGithub tries to use a common way to request GitHub v3 API. 

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/74cd6856de404dc3109360860b712d62458c24eb/github/Repository.py#L725-L739

Due to GitHub preview handling, each individual preview has its own MIME type(the `Accept` header) to enable it. I'm not sure it's good to use some MIME type by default. If I put the `mercy-preview` in default `Accept` header, there will be 33 fail tests. And if GitHub adds some new preview, we need to change the ReplayData again.

If any good idea, please tell me, I will change.

487301368.title: unable to get repo topics when using topics property
487301368.description:
### Problem

Recently, I found a problem on getting a repo's topics. If I use the `topics` property, it never work. But if I use the `get_topics` method, it will work.

```Python
from github import Github

token = open('./.token').read().strip()

g = Github(token)
repo = g.get_repo('PyGithub/PyGithub')
assert repo.topics is None
assert len(repo.get_topics()) == 4
```

### Environment

- PyGithub == 1.43.8
- Python == 3.7.4

The master branch (`a0f01cf`) has the same problem.

----
After check the source code of `get_topics`, I find that there should be have a specical header `"application/vnd.github.mercy-preview+json"`

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/a0f01cf9cf5521fd034813242727de72eb52df42/github/Repository.py#L2529-L2539

Thanks, I wanna submit a patch for this.

485904768.title: Incomplete results, retries not working, random exceptions
485904768.description:
Configuration:
g = Github({api_key}, per_page=100, retry=1000)

**1** - Retries do not execute, the program ends with an error
**2** - For some reason Exception behavior is highly unpredictable and it's maddening.
My program can effectively cycle and preemptively call the ratelimit api to check if it adheres within the limits for one to two hours before randomly getting a 403/50x .

Some native rate limit adherence would be a warm welcome here. Having to implement sleeps based on intuition when your application decides to spill the beans after two hours of running smoothly should not be expected behavior.
``` File "word.py", line 126, in get_stargazers_inner
    for i in repo.get_stargazers_with_dates():
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 62, in __iter__
    newElements = self._grow()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 74, in _grow
    newElements = self._fetchNextPage()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 199, in _fetchNextPage
    headers=self.__headers
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/Requester.py", line 276, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/Requester.py", line 287, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.RateLimitExceededException: 403 {'message': 'API rate limit exceeded for user ID xxxx.', 'documentation_url': 'https://developer.github.com/v3/#rate-limiting'}
```

Additionally, one could use the backoff library (function decorator with exponential backoff) -- however **it can not account for the current position in item iteration and will therefore start from scratch again**.
**3** - Incomplete results being returned
Example with keyword 'nyzo':
The api finds 28 results: https://api.github.com/search/repositories?q=nyzo
The library finds 15 results: https://i.imgur.com/XfjPI8i.png

comments.525593205:
For problem 1, I think you can use the `urllib3.util.Retry`, it provide more useful options to custom retry behavior.

Ref https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/urllib3.util.html#urllib3.util.retry.Retry

----
For problem 3, I could not reproduce. Here my test code.

```Python
from github import Github

token = open('./.token').read().strip()

g = Github(token, per_page=100, retry=1000)
repos = g.search_repositories('nyzo')
count = 0
for repo in repos:
    print(repo.full_name)
    count += 1
print(f'\nTotal: {count}')
```

I got 28 results.

484851353.title: Preview Handling
484851353.description:
Looking through https://developer.github.com/v3/previews/ it looks like each individual preview has its own MIME type to enable it, and there's no documented sequence to them (that is, it doesn't say that type U also covers types S and T, and there isn't a type Z that enables everything).

It looks like #1188 enables just one of these previews and touches 32 files in the process.

Maybe there's a better, more systemic way to handle this?

The current behavior is a single flag that enables the `moondragon` changes, which are from [2015](https://developer.github.com/changes/2015-01-07-prepare-for-organization-permissions-changes/) and were "merged" on June 24 of that year.

477863118.title: Add support to vulnerability alert and automated security fixes APIs
477863118.description:
- Add functions to get vulnerability alert information and change the vulnerability alert settings. 
- Add functions to change the automated security fixes settings. 


Unit tests cover:
- Normal case 
- when the repository does not exist (error 404)
- change automated security fix when vulnerability alert is disabled(error 424)
- get vulnerability when it is turned off(error 404).

Note: Those APIs are currently in preview status, feel free to reject it. 

Github API Documents:
- [get vulnerability settings](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#check-if-vulnerability-alerts-are-enabled-for-a-repository)
- [enable vulnerability alerts](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#enable-vulnerability-alerts)
- [disable vulnerability alerts](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#disable-vulnerability-alerts)
- [enable automated security fixes](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#enable-automated-security-fixes)
- [disable automated security fixes](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#disable-automated-security-fixes)

477164878.title: Drop use of assertEquals
477164878.description:
TestCase.assertEquals is deprecated, at least in modern Python 3, so
which to assertEqual, which is used everywhere else.

477119401.title: Remove more Python version specific code
477119401.description:
Remove a bunch of other call sites that behaved differently between
Python 2 and 3, massively cleaning up a few messy methods.

477098817.title: Delete Legacy submodule
477098817.description:
The Legacy module is unused, untested and has been untouched for seven
years. Drop it.

476665031.title: Remove some uses of atLeastPython3
476665031.description:
There are a number of call sites that would behave differently depending
on Python 2 or 3. A fair amount of them are left over from Python 3.2 or
Python 2.6 were the current versions, and it was much harder to write
compatible code for both versions. Happily, that is now in the past, so
refactor some of them out.

476648851.title: Fix directories for coverage in Travis
476648851.description:
The directory github/tests no longer exists, correct the path for Travis
goodness.

476645139.title: Switch to using six
476645139.description:
With the Python 2.7 deadline fast approaching, modernize the codebase
making use of the modernize module to switch to using six, as well as
other upcoming features, such as absolute imports . Stop using 2to3
for Travis, yay!

476601074.title: Label API: pass custom media type in the Accept header
476601074.description:
See #1101 for the corresponding issue and #1102 for the previous attempt at fixing it

As described in https://developer.github.com/changes/2018-02-22-label-description-search-preview/, a custom media type needs to be passed to the `Access` header to access label descriptions.

6a9fdd8 implements the new `Accept` header for getters methods of various classes
e73863a updates the unit tests accordingly

476276590.title: On issue edit/create/query, labels parameter is inconsistently used
476276590.description:
This is essentially the same behavior described in #222

When editing/creating/querying labels, some functions require labels to be passed as a Labels object and some require as a string. The preferred behavior would be to accept either a Label object or a string.

I'll submit a PR for this functionality.

comments.518306619: This is particularly odd when doing cross-repository querying of issues by label. Since the github issue querying API only accepts label *names* we can't possibly query by label *identity*, which is what passing a Label object appears to be doing.

474333730.title: Update Repository.update_file() docstring
474333730.description:
The docstring for Repository.update_file() insisted that content be
base64 encoded, which is not quite correct, update it.

Closes #1069

474110410.title: search_repositories() returns an incorrect number of results for queries.
474110410.description:
While direct use of the REST API v3 returns the complete enumeration of search results, `g.search_repositories()` returns an incomplete list of results.

For example, while `https://api.github.com/search/repositories?q=pony+language:python` shows that `total_count: 286`, `repositories.totalCount` is 111 for `repositories = g.search_repositories(query='pony+language:python')`. Indeed, after traversing through `repositories`, only 111 repositories are returned.

I hope there isn't something I missed in the documentation, but this is a rather serious issue. Thank you!

comments.516036582:
Here is my code for replication: 
```
from github import Github

g = Github("auth code")
repositories = g.search_repositories(query='pony+language:python')
print("There are at least", repositories.totalCount, "results under this query.")
i = 0
for repo in repositories:
    i += 1
    print(repo.created_at)
print(i)
```

473773255.title: Missing functionality to get all issues associated with a repository project
473773255.description:
Thanks for the very useful library. I am using the version `1.43.8` with Python version `3.6`.

I am wondering if there is a way to get all issues associate with a repository project.

I am unable to find a way to get all issues associated with a repository project (I have also not been able to find projects a given issue is associated with, which is very odd).

The raw data for an issue contains information for 'Assignees', 'Labels', and 'Milestone', but not 'Projects', which is shown right before 'Milestone' for every issue on the right-hand side of the GitHub interface, so there must be a straightforward way to get that information.

Any insights would be most welcome, and thank you very much for your time.

comments.518511212:
Getting all issues with a repository is via the Repository object:

```
>>> for i in list(g.get_repo('PyGithub/PyGithub').get_issues())[:5]:
...     print(i.number)
... 
1194
1193
1188
1187
1185
```

There is a repository method on Issue that returns the repository, like so:

```
>>> issue = g.get_repo('PyGithub/PyGithub').get_issue(1183)
>>> print(issue.repository.name)
PyGithub
```

473032235.title: Rate Limit Detection no longer works, string changed
473032235.description:
It seems that Github has changed the text that it sends when rate limiting. I have a script that uses a backoff decorator to retry on RateLimitExceededException, but now because the text has changed it throws a generic GithubException, which my decorator isn't catching.

This code here is looking for the strings that no longer exist. https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/828b53b7560b8c2b4e9d7064e0d9ffc442b16548/github/Requester.py#L310-L314

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 403 {'message': 'You have triggered an abuse detection mechanism. Please wait a few minutes before you try again.', 'documentation_url': 'https://developer.github.com/v3/#abuse-rate-limits'}
```

472314543.title: Creating code review changes PR data.
472314543.description:
I have some code that polls for pull requests, then, in some cases,
creates an automatic approval, like this:

    checked = set()
    ...
                # n is a Notification
                p = n.get_pull_request()
                if p.state == 'open':
                    print("Checking pull request {}.".format(p.id))
                    if p.id in checked:
                        continue
                    if ...
                        ...
                        p.create_review(event="APPROVE", body="")
                        n.mark_as_read()
                    checked.add(p.id)
    ...

This is actually not working like this, because `p.id` is being
modified!

There's this line in `PullRequest.py` in the `create_review` method:

```
        self._useAttributes(data)
```

That looks like it's taking the data from the pull request review and just applies it to itself ... that can't be right, can it? Before I create a PR then, what might have been the reason to have that call in there?

471538700.title: AuthUser lazy login field initialization and equality issue
471538700.description:
Hello,

I'm raising another issue as even though the fix is potentially quite straightforward, I can't seem to get the project building locally, due to various reasons.

Noticed it briefly yesterday, but if I obtain the authenticated user and print it as in the example bellow, the representation has no login information. However, if I manually print the login value, I will get the expected result.

```py
>>> auth_user = git.get_user()
>>> print(auth_user)
AuthenticatedUser(login=None)

>> print(auth_user.login)
dragosdumitrache
```

I suspect the issue might be because the `__repr__` method on `AuthenticatedUser` directly references the login value: `self._login.value`, instead of using the property `login()`. However, this is just a guess on my end, since I couldn't run the code locally.

Regarding local development, I am using Python 3.7.3, and the project only seems compatible with python2, is that correct? I'm asking so that in the future I can be more useful than just raising issues :)

L.E: Seems to print the correct representation if I manually check the `login` value and then print the entire object.
```py
>>> print(auth_user.login)
dragosdumitrache
>>> print(auth_user)
AuthenticatedUser(login=dragosdumitrache)
```

Furthermore, as it relates to `AuthenticatedUser`, is there a reason why `AuthenticatedUser` would not be equal to the equivalent `NamedUser`? There's no hash implementation

471124731.title: Fix URL encoding in GithubObject:__complete
471124731.description:
PyGithub currently fails on content retrieval due to '#' characters in URL path. This code path is hit when using GitHub code search and `GithubObject.py:__complete` is retrieving the i-th repo for `decoded_content`.

I fixed it similar to other instances in the codebase using `urllib.parse.quote`.

Example of search result that cannot be retrieved:
https://github.com/nbsullivan/hashtagcluster/blob/71c978ee41dc1ccdbdba8ee93507a2e418798ece/data/results/emmybatchpreds/#Emmys_batch5080usercount.csv

Returned from code search query:
`"user:nbsullivan GIFShare_es"`

471035264.title: MainGithub  get_organizations unexpected return type
471035264.description:
Hello. I have started writting a Git interaction tool for my current workplace. We have our own instance of GHE and organise everything into orgs. I have started used PyGithub, currently using v1.43.7, which should be the latest one.

Apologies if this has been asked before, I did have a look and could find nothing of the sort.

The `get_organizations` pydoc on the `MainClass.Github` seems to suggest that the returned type for `get_organizations` is a `PaginatedList` of `Organizations`, as can be seen at the following URL: 
[get_organizations docs](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github.html#github.MainClass.Github.get_organizations)

However, a successful call to `get_organizations` seems to return a `PaginatedList` of `NamedUser`, where each `NamedUser` is actually a git org (so it goes off and finds the right things on GHE, but returns the wrong type).

A quick fix to get the right type is to do something like this:

```py
named_users = git.get_organizations()
for named_user in named_users:
	actual_org = git.get_organization(named_user.login)
```

That is not in line with the documentation though, so I am wondering whether I am doing something wrong, or if this is the intended behaviour.

Kind regards,
Dragos

469459832.title: Specifying UnknownObjectExceptions
469459832.description:
Hello,

I'm writing a script to look for a directory of a certain name in a given repository, and if that directory doesn't exist, it throws an UnknownObjectException. I'd like to be able to specify the exception I'm catching as an UnknownObjectException, but I'm having trouble figuring out how to access that utility. Here's what I'm trying to do:
```
try:
    dir_test = repo.get_contents("test_directory")
except UnknownObjectException:
    print("This directory DNE")
```


And here's how I've tried to do it so far, and the resulting outputs:
```
except UnknownObjectException:
    # NameError: name 'UnknownObjectException' is not defined

except GithubException as ge:
    # NameError: name 'GithubException' is not defined

except Github(url, token).GithubException as ge:
    # AttributeError: 'Github' object has no attribute 'GithubException'

import github
except github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 
    # AttributeError: type object 'GithubException' has no attribute 'UnknownObjectException'
```

Any help as to how to go about specifying PyGithub exceptions would be greatly appreciated as I haven't found any examples online that have worked for me. Thanks!

468591267.title: Add support to vulnerability alert and automated security fixes APIs
468591267.description:
- Add functions to get vulnerability alert information and change the vulnerability alert settings. 
- Add functions to change the automated security fixes settings. 

Note: Those APIs are currently in preview status, feel free to reject it. 

Github API Documents:
- [get vulnerability settings](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#check-if-vulnerability-alerts-are-enabled-for-a-repository)
- [enable vulnerability alerts](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#enable-vulnerability-alerts)
- [disable vulnerability alerts](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#disable-vulnerability-alerts)
- [enable automated security fixes](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#enable-automated-security-fixes)
- [disable automated security fixes](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#disable-automated-security-fixes)

463142361.title: Organization.has_in_members uses incorrect URL if called from repository instance
463142361.description:
This works correctly (returns `True`):
```python
github_client = Github('token')
organization = github_client.get_organization('org')
user = github_client.get_user('user')
organization.has_in_members(user)
```

The same call from repo instance returns `False`:
```python
github_client = Github('token')
organization = github_client.get_organization('org')
user = github_client.get_user('user')
repo = organization.get_repo('repo')
repo.organization.has_in_members(user)
```

The reason is that requested URL is  referring to `users` namespace instead of `orgs`:
`https://api.github.com/users/...`

463087484.title: Silence more flake8 errors
463087484.description:
Make more whitespace changes to silence flake8 errors under the github
directory only.

461270311.description:

side effect of masking the tests.Repository import in AllTests with

drive-by, switch to using self.assertRaises for one of the tests.

459711088.title: Allow name to be specified for upload_asset
459711088.description:
GitRelease.upload_asset() calculates the name based on the filename, and
doesn't allow it to be overridden. Add a new name argument that is used
if it is set. Drive by changing the default of the content_type argument
to NotSet.

Closes #1095

459296226.title: Fetching a private repo fails (404)
459296226.description:
```python
>>> from github import Github
>>> github = Github("oauth token")
>>> github.get_repo("ddevault/test-repo") # GitHubException (404)
```

A similar request with curl succeeds:

```
$ curl -v -A 'PyGitHub/Python' \
    -H Accept:'application/vnd.github.v3+json' \
    -H Authorization:'token [redacted]' \
    https://api.github.com/repos/ddevault/test-repo # works
```

When trying to direct pygithub through mitmproxy to gather more information, it succeeds (200):

```
$ mitmproxy -m reverse:https:/api.github.com
```

```python
>>> from github import Github
>>> github = Github("oauth token", base_url="http://localhost:8080")
>>> github.get_repo("ddevault/test-repo") # works
```

459260120.title: Expose `get_issue_events()` from `PullRequest`
459260120.description:
I'm attempting to script automatically closing old Pull Requests, but letting users re-open them if they are still working on them. I don't want to *keep* closing PRs, so I want to check that a PR hasn't been re-opened before closing it. One way of doing that is to look through the list of "issue events", but first I need to use `PullRequest.as_issue()`, which makes a needless API request. 

Only the issue number is needed for `GET /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:issue_number/events`, so it should be possible to do directly from the `PullRequest` object. Any chance you could add that method? Similar to `PullRequest.get_issue_comments()` etc.

459152928.title: Missing support for license attribute in Repository

I have a PR for this issue.

458923075.title: Fix assertion in add_to_members
458923075.description:
The role parameter is set to NotSet by default
but the assertion only allowed str and unicode.
So it would always fail. Add NotSet to the assertion
to allow calling the function without a role.

Signed-off-by: Pascal Bach <pascal.bach@nextrem.ch>

458811833.title: What's the best way to get results in bulk?
458811833.description:
Is there a way for PyGitHub to return results as a bulk data dump?

## What I'd like

To be able to run a search query, and get a list of raw JSON, one for each item.

## What I've tried

I'll run a query with something like `search_issues(query)`, this returns a paginated list. I loop through the list, and on each "Issue" object I grab `raw_data` and turn it all into a DataFrame.

## Where I've run into challenges

I've found that returning a list of, e.g., issue objects and then looping through them individually takes a *lot* longer than if I just grab the JSON from the GitHub API directly. Is there some way to just get the whole dump of JSON objects at once rather than making an individual API request for each one?

comments.504620538: You can probably try GitHub V4 graphql.

457431475.title: topics attribute always return None, even when get_topics() return a list of topics
457431475.description:
For example:
`g.get_repo('nteract/hydrogen').topics` return `None`

`g.get_repo('nteract/hydrogen').get_topics()` return `['atom', 'data-science', 'hydrogen', 'ipython', 'jupyter', 'jupyter-kernels', 'nteract', 'repl']`

If I add `headers={"Accept": Consts.mediaTypeTopicsPreview}` to the repo request, I can get the topics list in the attribute as well.

I can create a PR if needed.

457019082.title: Persistence for PyGithubObjects from v1.19.0?
457019082.description:
[According to changes in version 1.19.0 ](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/doc/changes.rst#version-1190-september-8th-2013-akfishs-edition) there should be a `save` method for making `github.GithubObject.GithubObject` persistent. 

However, I cannot find the related code [where I would expect it](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/GithubObject.py) (the [related documentation](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects.html#github.GithubObject.GithubObject) does not also not list this functionality). 

What happened? I would love to have this feature!

456999705.title: Add support for the preview of the Vulnerability Alert APIs
456999705.description:
* Add support for the preview APIs related to Vulnerability Alerts on repositories (https://developer.github.com/changes/2019-04-24-vulnerability-alerts/) 
* Added support for three API endpoints:
    * `GET /repos/:owner/:repo/vulnerability-alerts`- Returns the status of Security Alerts for the repo
    * `PUT /repos/:owner/:repo/vulnerability-alerts` - Enable Security Alerts for the repo
    * `DELETE` /repos/:owner/:repo/vulnerability-alerts` - Disable Security Alerts for the repo

I had a need for this so I added it. Feel free to reject this if you want to wait for full official support for the APIs. 

The APIs require owner permissions for the repository in question. I haven't written any checks to see if permissions are correct or not.

comments.503918064: Hi @chrihala Thank you very much for your PR. It would be helpful if you can add a unit test. You can refer to the contribution [docs](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#automated-tests) for instructions.

455926270.title: Replacing a specified string, Iterating over every file within every repo.
455926270.description:
Hello,

Sorry for the long title.

Essentially, I am attempting to write a script which will iterate over every repository I own. Then for a specific string and if found in any of the files within the repo; replace it.

Is this possible? I am aware I need to also use `update_file`. Could somebody point me in the right direction?

So far I have got:

```python
"""
A Python 3.7 script to remove a specific string from all file(s) and repos containing a specified string.
"""

ACCESS_TOKEN = "Sometoken"
STR_TO_REPLACE = "The string to find in a file and remove."

from github import Github

g = Github(ACCESS_TOKEN)
for repo in g.get_user().get_repos(type="owner"):
    print(repo.name)
    # Fetch all content from the repo.
    repo_contents = repo.get_contents("")
    # Show all repo contents.
    print(repo_contents)
    for file in repo_contents:
        print(file.name)
        try:
            # Search the file for the specified string and replace it with something else.
            # Not sure how to do this yet. This is where I need some help :-)
        except:
            # Some error which occurs if the string is not found. 
            # Tell user the string isn't in the file.
            print(f"The string {STR_TO_REPLACE} wasn't found in {file.name}")
```

Any help would be appreciated.

454822411.title: Paginated list reversed only gives the first page of results backwards
454822411.description:
When I do
```
g = Github("xxx")
repo = g.get_repo("xxx")

for comm in repo.get_commits(since=datetime).reversed:
    ....
```
it only goes through the most recent 30 results in reverse order.

I was able to fix this with
```
def reverse_github_results(paginated_list):
    for i in range(paginated_list.totalCount//30, -1, -1):
        page = paginated_list.get_page(i)
        page.reverse()
        for item in page:
            yield item
```
but this possibly runs a bit slower and I thought I should let you guys know

451114821.title: Add two factor attributes on organizations
451114821.description:
If you have the role of `org:admin` on an organization, you can view whether or not a second factor is required in order to be a member of an organization. (See https://developer.github.com/v3/orgs/#get-an-organization for more information). This PR adds `two_factor_requirement_enabled` as an attribute to the organization model. 

If a user doesn't have the correct permissions set on their personal access token or doesn't have `org:admin`, this value will be null in the JSON and `None` in pygithub.

441228055.title: github.GithubException.RateLimitExceededException
441228055.description:
I am trying to fetch the number of open issues using the following code in my Flask application.
```
g = Github()

repo = g.get_repo(repo_name)

open_pulls = repo.get_pulls(state='open')
open_pull_titles = [pull.title for pull in open_pulls]

open_issues = repo.get_issues(state='open')
open_issues = [issue for issue in open_issues if issue.title not in open_pull_titles]
```
and I get the error `github.GithubException.RateLimitExceededException: `.

`repo.get_issues()` returns the count of open issues plus pull requests.

comments.490124359: If I understand correctly, the return type of get_issues and get_pulls is PaginatedList.   It uses `yield element` for iteration. So the request is not performed until `open_issues = [issue for issue in open_issues if issue.title not in open_pull_titles]`.  If your token limits are reached, it will throw the RateLimitExceedException.

        self.github_api.git_repo.get_file_contents(urllib.quote('file with spaces.txt') , "master")
fails

        self.github_api.git_repo.get_file_contents(urllib.quote('/iOS/Supporting Files/Info.plist') , "master")  
also fails, yet works in 1.35 

This is blocking us from moving to later versions, as it breaks our release automation scripts.

435840469.title: Move tests/ back into github/tests and ship within tarball, or at least provide github.testing?
435840469.description:
#1031 recently placed `tests/` outside of the `github` package. The main reasoning, if I got it right from #672, is the size -- tests indeed add up to the distribution.  I personally from time to time  do run tests of the package I am "questioning", which cannot be done if no `tests/` shipped.  To my knowledge, many (if not most) packages do ship `tests` subpackages as part of their packages. 
Moreover, my use case is actually to consider using `github.tests.Framework`  in our ([datalad](http://datalad.org)) tests to verify correct operation of our code which makes use of the `github` package.   I am not sure if that might be advised against, but now I wouldn't even be able to do so since there is no installed `github.tests` module.  If you see `Framework` to be potentially reused by 3rd party packages like ours, and if you insist that no `tests/` shipped as part of the `github` package, may be it makes sense then to move `Framework` components to e.g. `github.testing` (analogous to `numpy.testing` etc)?

comments.491017492:
I have exactly the same problem, I'm importing the Framework and this update broke my CI :(
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1050156/57477678-13feec00-724e-11e9-99ff-6ac29fbe4a89.png)

I have using your class which was part of the public API of the package to record my own high level tests, and now I have to pin the PyGithub version until I have time to replace it with something else (vcrpy?)

I understand if you don't want to go back to your decision, but at least I wanted to point the impact: since this naming was public (no underscore), it becomes automatically part of the public API and changing it is a breaking change that should required a major version bump (and not a patch version :()

432540142.title: search_commits, missing repository key
432540142.description:
I would like to get a GitHub Repository URL from a Commit HASH. This is feasible with the API:

```python
    import json
    import requests
    
    def search_commits(sha):
       headers = {'Accept': 'application/vnd.github.cloak-preview'}
       req = requests.get('http://api.github.com/search/commits',
           {'q': sha},
           headers=headers)
       return json.loads(req.text)
    
    commit = search_commits('e83c5163316f89bfbde7d9ab23ca2e25604af290')['items'][0]
    clone_url = commit['repository']['url']
```

Then I tried the same with `PyGitHub`:

```python
    from github import Github
    g = Github()
    
    commit = g.search_commits('e83c5163316f89bfbde7d9ab23ca2e25604af290')[0]
```

Unfortunately in this result (even in `commit.raw_data`) there is no key `repository`. 

It seems PyGitHub uses `search/commits` as described here: https://developer.github.com/v3/search/#search-commits

But instead of this object it returns a Commit object https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/commits/

How can I get the URL of the repository?

comments.482566327: Unfortunately since the Commit object does not have a `repository` attribute, I guess the work-around is just to use the `commit['url']` and some string manipulation.

431216641.title: Use non-deprecated path for creating GitHub App access tokens
431216641.description:
👋 Hey friends

`/installations/<installation_id>/access_tokens` has been [deprecated](https://developer.github.com/changes/2018-08-16-renaming-and-deprecation-of-github-app-installation-access-token-route/) but it has a drop-in replacement at  `/app/installations/<installation_id>/access_tokens`.

This updates `get_access_token` and associated test to use the non-deprecated URL.

```sh
$ python -m github.tests GithubIntegration                                                                                                                                                                                                  update_access_token_path ✔
..
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 2 tests in 0.106s

OK
```

430939709.title: Caching API data
430939709.description:
A simple loop such as:

```
            for review in self.pull_request.get_reviews():
                if review.user and review.user.name and \
                   review.user.name.startswith("foobar") and \
                   review.state == "CHANGES_REQUESTED":
                    ...
```

Seems to produce a huge number of repeated `GET https://api.github.com/users/<username>` calls.  I believe this ends up triggering abuse rate-limiting:

```
[2019-04-09T10:02:14.101Z] 2019-04-09 10:02:11,214 POST https://api.github.com/.../pulls/284/reviews {'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Authorization': 'Basic (login and password removed)', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'} {...} ==> 422 {'status': '422 Unprocessable Entity', 'x-accepted-oauth-scopes': '', 'content-length': '171', 'x-github-media-type': 'github.v3; format=json', 'content-security-policy': "default-src 'none'", 'x-content-type-options': 'nosniff', 'access-control-expose-headers': 'ETag, Link, Location, Retry-After, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval, X-GitHub-Media-Type', 'x-github-request-id': '9F34:7C5C:3ABC39:7696C8:5CAC6DA0', 'strict-transport-security': 'max-age=31536000; includeSubdomains; preload', 'x-ratelimit-remaining': '4719', 'server': 'GitHub.com', 'x-ratelimit-limit': '5000', 'x-oauth-scopes': 'notifications, public_repo', 'date': 'Tue, 09 Apr 2019 10:02:11 GMT', 'x-frame-options': 'deny', 'access-control-allow-origin': '*', 'referrer-policy': 'origin-when-cross-origin, strict-origin-when-cross-origin', 'content-type': 'application/json; charset=utf-8', 'x-xss-protection': '1; mode=block', 'x-ratelimit-reset': '1554806424'} {"message":"Unprocessable Entity","errors":["was submitted too quickly"],"documentation_url":"https://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/reviews/#create-a-pull-request-review"}
```

Surely the library doesn't need to repeatedly get the same user info from the API and can instead cache it after the first fetch, yes?

424104590.title: Handle a path of / in Repository.get_contents()
424104590.description:
The path requested in Repository.get_contents() is appended to the URL,
so the root path should be requested with the empty string. If path is
'/', set it to the empty string. Copy the replay data from the original
test, since it is identical.

Drive-by renaming the test to include the missing 's'.

Closes #1059

421761329.title: commit.last_modified returns wrong date when retrieved from tags list
421761329.description:
## The problem

Hey there, 

It seems that the value returned by the `last_modified` attribute of a given commit differs if we obtain this commit from the repository's tags list.

## Example

 ```{python}
from github import Github
gh = Github()
repo = gh.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
tag_commit = repo.get_tags()[0].commit
commit = repo.get_commit(tag_commit.sha)

# same commit sha
print("{} -- {}".format(tag_commit.sha, commit.sha))

# different last_modified dates
print("{} -- {}".format(tag_commit.last_modified, commit.last_modified))
```

## Environment

* Python: 3.7
* PyGithub: 1.43.5

comments.479937414: This is related to #629 and I fixed this in #1032. It works for all practical purposes but some unrelated tests are failing so I will see if I can fix those.

421669691.title: Add support for the Checks API
421669691.description:
The Github v3 API now supports a first-class notion of [check runs] and [check suites] that can be used to gate whether a pull-request should be merged or not.

Adding support for this part of the API to PyGithub would be useful for users who want to develop custom checks.  As I'm in that case, I might have a stab at this, but simply didn't make the time yet.

[check runs]: https://developer.github.com/v3/checks/runs/
[check suites]: https://developer.github.com/v3/checks/suites/

comments.477908582:
It would be really great to support this API indeed 👍 

We are currently using pygithub to add comments automatically to our PRs from our CI jobs. However, we would like to switch to the Checks API in order to keep the discussion cleaner.

411033681.title: Repository.get_git_ref doesn't handle prefix matches
411033681.description:
### Description

**Version**: 1.43.5

The `get_git_ref` function doesn't handle the case where `ref` is not found, but other refs prefixed by `ref` exist. The `get_git_ref` function should either return a list of `GitRefs` in this case or raise `UnknownObjectException`.

From the [documentation](https://developer.github.com/v3/git/refs/):

> If the ref doesn't exist in the repository, but existing refs start with ref they will be returned as an array. For example, a call to get the data for a branch named feature, which doesn't exist, would return head refs including featureA and featureB which do.

### Demonstration

Single object returned when ref exists, as expected:
```py
In [23]: ref = repo.get_git_ref('tags/bar')

In [24]: ref
Out[24]: GitRef(ref="refs/tags/bar")

In [25]: ref._rawData
Out[25]:
{'node_id': 'MDM6UmVmNTE5NjI3MzpiYXI=',
 'object': {'sha': '70ed626e0fec6d033b5066a322ce77565e67f0ff',
  'type': 'commit',
  'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/commits/70ed626e0fec6d033b5066a322ce77565e67f0ff'},
 'ref': 'refs/tags/bar',
 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/refs/tags/bar'}
```

"Null" ref returned when ref not found, but multiple prefix matches found:

```py
In [26]: ref = repo.get_git_ref('heads/bar')

In [27]: ref
Out[27]: GitRef(ref=None)

In [28]: ref._rawData
Out[28]:
[{'node_id': 'MDM6UmVmNTE5NjI3MzpiYXJfMQ==',
  'object': {'sha': '70ed626e0fec6d033b5066a322ce77565e67f0ff',
   'type': 'commit',
   'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/commits/70ed626e0fec6d033b5066a322ce77565e67f0ff'},
  'ref': 'refs/heads/bar_1',
  'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/refs/heads/bar_1'},
 {'node_id': 'MDM6UmVmNTE5NjI3MzpiYXJfMg==',
  'object': {'sha': 'baf8b0ebbe4c9974a6a255557efd61f2c51751e3',
   'type': 'commit',
   'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/commits/baf8b0ebbe4c9974a6a255557efd61f2c51751e3'},
  'ref': 'refs/heads/bar_2',
  'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/repo/www/git/refs/heads/bar_2'}]
```
### Conclusion
I understand this is an edge case, but most people probably don't expect to ever receive a "null" ref in this case. The least surprising thing to do here may be to raise `UnknownObjectException` if there is no exact match for `ref`. Additionally, there may be value in providing a flag to return prefix match results instead of throwing an exception.

406550869.title: [WIP] Replace broken edit_user|team_push_restrictions with full implementation of the API
406550869.description:
[Here is the relevant Github API documentation](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#list-team-restrictions-of-protected-branch).

As can be seen from the docs, `edit_*_push_restrictions` is a misnomer. In the current API, [POST will only *add*, never remove](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#add-team-restrictions-of-protected-branch). This commit adds a more fine-grained API:

* `add_user|team_push_restrictions` (`POST`)
* `replace_user|team_push_restrictions` (`PUT`)
* `remove_user|team_push_restrictions` (`DELETE`)

`replace_user|team_push_restriction` could also be called `edit_user|team_push_restriction` but I find the name slightly misleading. It also can't safely replace the old `edit_user|team_push_restriction` functions as those would have only ever added users or teams.

The way this PR is built right now, it's a breaking change. Advice and opinions on alternative approaches are welcome.

405729673.title: Retreive commits in ref in parent child order
405729673.description:
I'm using pyGithub to automate building of a testing branch from outstanding PRs marked as ready for testing.

To do that I query all the commits in the ref associated with the PR and build a pick list of commits to cherry-pick on to the upstream base.

In general its working great, however the commits in the commit list of a PR come seem to be listed in the same order that github shows them in.  This is ordered by commit date instead of by parent child (a "feature" I really don't like BTW)

Because of this my tool will build a cherry-pick list of commits in the wrong order which causes merge conflicts. 

Is there a way to get the list of commits associated with the PR in parent child order instead of date?

comments.479057764: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

405546892.title: Fixed File.last_modified attribute
405546892.description:
This attribute now contains the correct last modification date for the file in question (and not the repository as a whole).
Fixes #629.

405272230.title: Updated setup.py to exclude tests
405272230.description:
# Problem #
The `.whl` available on PyPi for this repository contains its entire `tests` submodule. 

The total size of the `pygithub` module is less than `1mb` without tests and `>23mb` with. 

Previous discussions on this topic indicated the removal of tests would be accepted if someone created a pull request to do so: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/672 

This is that pull request! 😄

# Solution/Implementation # 

- Moved "tests" to root of the repository ( outside the package ) 
    - Added `tests.` module path to the imports in `AllTests.py`
- Updated `setup.py`
    - Removed `package_data` from product
    - Removed "tests" from packages definition
    - Repointed `test_suite` to new location
- Updated `travis.yml`
    - Added conditional ( if not `py2.7` ) conversion of code to `py3`

_... apologies for all the failed build spam below - new to working with Travis CI / had some gotcha moments!_

405246332.title: Organization.add_to_members() doesn't pass role correctly
405246332.description:
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Organization.html#github.Organization.Organization.add_to_members passes the role as part of the query string: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Organization.py#L316

But Github expects it as a JSON payload. As a result, all new members are created as `member` (not as `admin`), and you can't update an organization member to `admin` with PyGithub.

405195905.title: add has_organization_projects and has_repository_projects
405195905.description: These are just two missing booleans from https://developer.github.com/v3/orgs/#get-an-organization

405144474.title: Travis CI: Add Python 3.7 to the testing
405144474.description:
Also:
* Python 3.4 reaches its end of life in 44 days so let's remove it from the testing.  https://devguide.python.org/#branchstatus
* [Travis are now recommending removing the __sudo__ tag](https://blog.travis-ci.com/2018-11-19-required-linux-infrastructure-migration).

405140145.title: Add six to requirements.txt and setup.py
405140145.description:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/setup.py#L105 relies on the setuptools __use_2to3__ "feature" that is no longer recommended. The Setuptools docs https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python3.html say _Setuptools provides a facility to invoke 2to3 on the code as a part of the build process, by setting the keyword parameter __use_2to3__ to True, but the Setuptools project strongly recommends instead developing a unified codebase using __six__, __future__, or another compatibility library._

This PR adds the broadly used Python 2 and 3 compatibility library [__six__](https://pypi.org/project/six/) to requirements.txt.  This will allow the use of [__six.text_type__](https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.string_types) as an effective replacement for __unicode__ which was removed in Python 3 and [__six.string_types__](https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.string_types) as an effective replacement for __basestring__ (or __(str, unicode)__) which was removed in Python 3.

405127070.title: 01 is a syntax error in Python 3
405127070.description:
@sfdye Can I please get your help in closing these syntax error?

$ __python3 -c "01"__  # --> SyntaxError: invalid token
* https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.0.html?highlight=octal%20literals#integers

In Python 3:
* __1__ is decimal one
* __0o1__ is octal one
* __01__ is a syntax error

405123490.title: Old style exceptions --> new style for Python 3
405123490.description: @sfdye Can I please get your help in closing these __syntax errors__? Old style exceptions are syntax errors in Python 3 but new style exceptions work as expected in both Python 2 and Python 3.

405113721.title: Use print() function in both Python 2 and Python 3
405113721.description: @sfdye Can I please get your help in closing these syntax errors?  Legacy __print__ statements are syntax errors in Python 3 but __print()__ function works as expected in both Python 2 and Python 3.

404686768.title: get_access_token is broken >= 1.43.3
404686768.description:
Looks like the fix in #1010 only fixed a part of the problem(s) introduced in 1.43.4. With 1.43.5 I get:

```
File "/.tox/test/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/MainClass.py", line 790, in get_access_token
response_text = response_text.decode('utf-8')
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'decode'
```

404446981.title: PUT /orgs/:org/memberships/:username requires role parameter to be in the body
404446981.description:
The documentation doesn't make it clear, but it seems that the `role` parameter must be part of the JSON PUT body instead of the URL parameters. With the current code, it's not possible to change a user's role to an admin because the URL parameter gets ignored.

This behavior was observed with GitHub Enterprise 2.14.10 and seems to appear in the replay data in this repo too: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/f0e0762a0d286dab47146f9357b06714a86d3c25/github/tests/ReplayData/Organization.testAddMembersAdminRole.txt#L23-L32

403230238.title: Implement OAuth for apps
403230238.description:
This PR adds support for:
* Getting OAuth login URL for apps
* Getting access tokens for apps
* Listing app installations that are accessible to a user

Related to #828

400462789.title: get_issues() since=date gets older issues
400462789.description:
Hi all, i tried to get closed issues of PyGithub since 1st January 2019 with this simple code
```
PyGit = client.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")

date = datetime(2019, 1, 1, 0, 0)
issues = PyGit.get_issues(state="closed", since=date, sort="closed-desc")
for issue in issues:
	print(issue, issue.closed_at)
```
but what i get is this

> Issue(title="Github App unable to invite to org", number=1018) 2019-01-16 15:37:19
> Issue(title="dummy issue #911", number=1017) 2019-01-15 08:29:21
> Issue(title="GithubException: Repository access blocked", number=1015) 2019-01-15 19:50:33
> Issue(title="Add missing import to PullRequest", number=1007) 2019-01-04 14:28:54
> Issue(title="get_review_comments() method fails due to missing import", number=1004) 2019-01-04 14:28:54
> Issue(title="user.node_id missing", number=1001) 2019-01-10 12:49:53
> Issue(title="user.node_id missing ", number=999) 2019-01-10 12:50:52
> Issue(title="raise BadCredentialException when using Github enterprise", number=950) 2019-01-01 13:21:15
> Issue(title="BadCredentialsException not raised on GitHub enterprise", number=934) 2019-01-15 22:53:42
> Issue(title="create PullRequest between forked repo to original", number=792) 2018-05-18 02:52:21
> Issue(title="Implement `__len__` (and/or `__bool__`) on PaginatedList", number=579) 2019-01-15 22:53:41
> Issue(title="GitHub integrations support", number=449) 2017-01-27 16:34:41

how is this possible if I specified date with "since" option?

399417347.title: Github App unable to invite to org
399417347.description:
Python 3.6
Code I'm using:
``` 
from github import GithubIntegration, Github

private_key = open('pem.pem').read()

integration_id = XXX
installation_id = YYY

integration = GithubIntegration(integration_id, private_key)
auth = integration.get_access_token(installation_id)
g = Github(auth.token)

org = g.get_organization('<org-name>')

org.invite_user(email="email@email.com")
```

I'm unable to invite a user/email, I get the following error:
`{
    "message": "Validation Failed",
    "errors": [
        {
            "resource": "OrganizationInvitation",
            "code": "unprocessable",
            "field": "data",
            "message": "Inviter must be an organization admin"
        }
    ],
    "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/v3/orgs/members/#create-organization-invitation"
}`

Using that token though I'm able to list teams within the org, list repos, etc. Only thing I'm unable to do is invite users, which is what this whole app is meant to do.

EDIT: Wanted to add that I'm an admin/owner in the org, and I'm the one who created and added the Github App to the Org.

The App has the following permissions:
Organization members : Read & Write

398552928.title: Add assignee addition/removal support for Pull Requests
398552928.description:
Fixes #1009 

This is my first contribution here, so please let me know if I am missing anything. I added a test case, but since I don't have access to this repo to add/remove assignees, I wasn't able to completely run the test with the users specified. 🤞 I used the examples already written for the same function in [Issue.py](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/tests/Issue.py).

Note: Since the [Assignees](https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/assignees/) API uses issues as a shared endpoint for PRs and Issues, the PR object must be converted to an Issue by using `as_issue()` before assignees can be added or removed from a PR.

Usage:
```
user = github_api.get_user('user')
repo = user.get_repo('repo')
pr = repo.get_pull(1)
pr_issue = pr.as_issue()
pr_issue.add_to_assignees('assignee1', 'assignee2')
pr_issue.remove_from_assignees('assignee1', 'assignee2')
```

397606988.title: The number of contributors not correct using PyGithub
397606988.description:
I am using following code to get the number of contributors of a repository

```
from github import Github
g = Github("*****github Access token****")
repo = g.get_repo('mui-org/material-ui')
contributors_count = repo.get_contributors().totalCount
```
It is giving number of contributors as **443**, however, the correct number of contributors on the github website is **1077**.

Can some one tell why am I getting different values?

Also, is there any other function in PyGithub to get correct number of contributors?

397411693.title: Allow unicode type in PullRequest.create_review

`create_review` method of `PeullRequest` asserts `body` to be a type of
`str`. Let's allow to have `unicode` there as well.

396865243.title: fix request got an unexpected keyword argument body

396808247.title: how to create "lightweight" tag?
396808247.description:
There are "lightweight tag" and "annotated tag".

The tag `0.3.6` was created in the app as "lightweight". (Git Extensions app)
The tag `4.0.0`, I believe, is marked as annotated with `[...]` string. 

![](https://i.imgur.com/1wcjhJt.png)


The tag `4.0.0` was created as:
``` py
sha = repo.get_commits()[0].sha
t = repo.create_git_tag(tag="4.0.0", message="Test", object=sha, type="commit")
repo.create_git_ref('refs/tags/{}'.format(t.tag), t.sha)
```
How to create a "lightweight" tag?

------------
UPD.
Answer:
``` py
sha = repo.get_commits()[0].sha
repo.create_git_ref('refs/tags/{}'.format("4.0.0"), sha)
```

396263340.title: How to assign a user to a pull request recently created?
396263340.description:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5332158/50737362-54bafb80-11af-11e9-8dad-74ab04d8dcae.png)

```python
fork_user = github_api.get_user('user')
fork_repo = fork_user.get_repo('repo')

fork_pullrequest = fork_repo.create_pull("Title", "Body", 'master', 
          '{}:{}'.format('otheruser', 'master'), False)
```

After running this code, I got the pull_request object. Looking over its documentation at:
1. https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html

I could not find a method to assign a user to the pull request like:
```python
fork_pullrequest.assign(fork_user)
```

comments.453746361: Hi @evandrocoan - I implemented this feature request in #1016.

395842177.title: No longer blindly mask JSON parsing errors
395842177.description:
If the JSON returned fails to parse *for whatever reason*, it is wrapped
in a dictionary and blindly passed on. Where, for example, PaginatedList
then returns a mostly unpopulated object and raises an URL exception
when attempting to complete it. This has wasted my time for the last
time. Clean up all of the unparseble JSON in the replay data (which is
only fair, since I added most of it), and only wrap the data if it
starts with a <html> tag to deal with 503 errors and the like.

comments.451379953: As an another idea, we could rip that special case out, and only try and to tease out JSON if the response isn't 5xx. I was tempted to say only 200, but GitHub annoying makes use of lots of 4xx responses in its API.

395815591.title: Add missing import to PullRequest
395815591.description:
PullRequest.get_review_comments() works with no arguments passed due to
if short circuiting, but as soon as you pass since, you get an exception
since datetime wasn't imported. Import it, and add a test case for good
measure.

Closes #1004

395764674.title: PaginatedList.totalCount KeyError: 'page' with large results
395764674.description:
When using get_repo().totalCount on a small result set (only my own repositories) totalCount returns the repository count correctly. When querying my enterprise Github for a complete list of repositories, the following error occurs:

```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test-repo-list.py", line 9, in <module>
    print("Found %s repositories." % full_repo_list.totalCount)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 175, in totalCount
    self.__totalCount = int(parse_qs(lastUrl)['page'][0])
KeyError: 'page'
````

I am using Python 3.7.1 and the pip-installed version 1.43.4 of PyGithub with a Github Enterprise version 2.14.7.

This is the code I have used to test this:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3.7
from github import Github
import os

api_token = os.getenv('GITHUB_TOKEN', None)
g = Github(base_url="https://mygithubhost.lads", login_or_token=api_token)

full_repo_list = g.get_repos()
print("Found %s repositories." % full_repo_list.totalCount)
```

I did notice, after some skimming of PaginatedList.py, that the Link headers differ between the two tests. When collecting just my own repositories, I see the "last" link returned in the link header, but when querying for all repositories I only see "next" and "first" links returned.

g.get_user().get_repos():
```json
'link':'<https://mygithubhost.lads/api/v3/user/repos?per_page=1&page=2>; rel="next", <https://mygithubhost.lads/api/v3/user/repos?per_page=1& 
page=10>; rel="last"'`
```

g.get_repos():
```json
'link':'<https://mygithubhost.lads/api/v3/repositories?per_page=1&since=112>; rel="next", <https://mygithubhost.lads/api/v3/repositories{?since}>; rel="first"'
```

I don't know what's causing this difference in behavior, though.

If I don't try to get totalCount from the object, it works as expected, but totalCount specifically seems to fail.

comments.453972539:
Maybe, From the [list-all-public-repositories API](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#list-all-public-repositories) doc.

> Note: Pagination is powered **exclusively** by the since parameter. Use the Link header to get the URL for the next page of repositories.

It not support `per_page` parameter, so the pagination strategy is not working. But I don't know why there is no last` link returned in the link header.

395463297.title: Question: Topics Preview on search repositories
395463297.description:
Understanding of the preview state here, opening this up more as a question and open to alternative implementation (e.g. an opt-in flag).  Would this approach be merged in directly?

In relation to:

> Note: The topics property for repositories on GitHub is currently available for developers to preview. To view the topics property in calls that return repository results, you must provide a custom media type in the Accept header: `application/vnd.github.mercy-preview+json`

https://developer.github.com/v3/search/#search-repositories

394687569.title: get_review_comments() method fails due to missing import
394687569.description:
Specifically this line:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/PullRequest.py#L552
requires that the `datetime` module be loaded. It isn't.

Adding a 
```python
import datetime
```
at the top of `github/PullRequest.py` fixes this bug.

I checked the test coverage and indeed there doesn't seem to be a test of this method.

394250374.title: add: create project column card route
394250374.description:
Add the missing route to create cards for projects columns
Test written and passing locally.

394197315.title: Adding communications Retry functionality into requests via urllib3 retry object.
394197315.description:
This is a continuation of the work started by @allevin on https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/860.

I have refactored the testing Framework to use the `httpretty` library in order to use the urllib3 retry feature and therefore be able to test it.

Please refer to https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/860 for additional context.

cc: @allevin @mfonville @jrouquie @sfdye

Closes #757 
Closes #860

394192559.title: user.node_id missing
394192559.description:
'node_id' attribute was missing. Hence added the attribute using add_attribute script in AuthorizedUser  and NamedUser classes. 
This fixes issue #999 .
